form.definition: noun B or b is the second letter of the English alphabet.
noun In music, B is the seventh note in the scale of C major.
noun If you get a B mark in class or for an exam, your work is above average. 'B' is the second highest grade that you can get.
abbreviation for born. ...Joan Sutherland b. 1926.
verb When someone babbles, they talk quickly and unclearly, or in a foolish way. The interviewer made me so nervous I just started babbling.[qr

dictionary.entry:
baby`bEIbi:babies
noun A baby is a very young child or animal. She's expecting a baby. ...a baby elephant.
noun You call someone a baby when they behave like a young child. Stop crying, you baby!
noun The baby of the family is the youngest child.
noun You can call something your baby if you like doing it very much or if you're in charge of it. Don't worry about the holiday rosterthat's the manager's baby.

form.definition: verb When you babysit, you look after someone's children for a short time while the parents are out.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun babysitter

form.definition: noun A bachelor is an unmarried man.
noun Your back is the rear part of your body, and goes from your neck to the bottom of your spine. See the picture at body. You'll really hurt your back if you keep lifting things the wrong way.
noun The back of something is the rear side of it. The opposite of this is front. I'll hit it with the back of the spade. ...the back of your hand. There's a hook on the back of the door.

verb If you back a car or some other vehicle, you drive it backwards. Other words for this are reverse and back up. I'll back the car out so we can clean ~the garage. Back the trailer into the driveway.
verb If you back someone, you help them by lending them the money they need or by supporting their plans. Who's backing you in your new business? That's a good ideaI'll back it in the meeting.
verb If you back a horse or a dog in a race, you bet money that it will win.
adverb If you move or stand back, you move or stand further away or closer to the rear. Everyone move back! The ambulance can't get through. You need to be further back to see the painting properly.

adverb You can say someone or something is back if they are where they were at some time before. It's great to have Maria back again. I'll put this back when I've finished with it. When you're back in Poland, send me some stamps.
back up (a) If you back up, you drive a vehicle backwards. Can you back up so I can get my car out? Back it up but watch out for the fence!
(b) If you back up information on your computer, you copy it onto another computer or onto a disk. This means you have a in case something goes wrong.
the back The back of something is the part which is furthest away from the front. I found a seat at the back of the bus. The teacher told him to stand at the back.
noun Your backbone is the row of bones running down the middle of your back. Another word for this is spine.
noun You say someone has backbone if you think they have courage. Show some backbone and speak up for what you believe in!
noun The backbone of an organisation or system is the part that gives it its main strength and support. The wool industry used to be the backbone of the Australian economy.
verb If you backdate a document or a cheque, you give it a date which is earlier than the actual date.
verb If you backdate a policy or a decision, you make it apply from an earlier date. The workers were given a pay rise of 4%, backdated to April.
verb When a car engine backfires, it makes a loud explosive sound from the exhaust pipe. My car needs fixingit keeps backfiring.
verb You say a plan backfires when it doesn't work out the way you wanted it to. Her scheme backfired on her when the boss found out about it.
noun The background is what you see behind the main features of a picture or scene. The opposite of this is foreground. The background's too dark to see their faces clearly.

noun Someone's background is the sort of family they come from or the experiences that they've had. Fred's got a working-class background and he's proud of it. We need someone with a background in computing.

noun The background to a situation is the events or facts that help you to understand it. The war took place against a background of international tension caused by high inflation and rising oil prices.

noun Backing is money or support that you give someone to help them carry out their plans. The project failed because it didn't get government backing. You'll certainly have my backing if you suggest those changes.
noun A backlog is a large number of jobs to do that should have been already completed. After the Christmas holidays, there's always a backlog of enquiries to answer.
noun Backside is an informal word for your buttocks or bottom. I landed flat on my backside. Why doesn't she get off her backside and help us?
form.note: ... OTHER INFORMAL WORDSfor this are bum and arse. Arse is ruder than bum and backside.

form.definition: noun If someone or something is your backstop, you are relying on them to help you when things that you plan do not turn out as you hoped. I've applied for some other jobs as a backstop. That $1000 will be a useful backstop.
noun In sport, a backstop is a player on the field, or sometimes an object such as a fence, whose job is to stop the ball from going too far out of play.
noun Backstroke is a style of swimming in which you lie on your back and pull yourself through the water by rotating ~your arms backwards into the water behind you.
form.note: ... NOTEOther styles of swimming are: breaststroke; freestyle, or crawl; and butterfly.

form.definition: noun A backup is extra help or equipment. Every boat should have an extra motor as a backup. Remember to make a backup on a floppy disk.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective backup We'll need backup staff to do the job.

form.definition: adjective A backward movement or look is directed toward the rear. The opposite of this is forward. Can you do a backward somersault? She walked away without a back-ward glance.

adjective People say something is backward when they believe it has not developed enough. The opposite of this is advanced or developed. Chris thinks the company is backward because it hasn't got its own desktop publishing unit.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun backwardness

form.definition: adverb If something moves backwards, it moves towards the rear. The opposite of this is forwards. The car rolled backwards down the hill.
adverb If you look backwards, you look behind you.
adverb If you do something backwards, you do it the opposite way to normal. Can you count backwards from 100?
adverb If you know something backwards, you know it very well. Let's ask Carlos. He knows the safety regulations backwards.
noun A backyard is the enclosed area of grass and garden behind a house. Why don't we have a barbecue in the backyard?

adjective A small part-time business, usually operated from someone's home, is called a backyard business. People who run such a business are usually unqualified. Whatever you do, don't have your car fixed by a backyard mechanic.
noun Bacon is the meat taken from the back and sides of pigs. It is salted and then either dried or smoked.
noun Bacteria are tiny microscopic organisms that can cause disease. Milk is pasteurised to kill harmful bacteria.
form.note: ... NOTEThis is a plural word. The singular form is bacterium. ... WORD FAMILY adjective bacterial

form.definition: adjective Something is bad when it is unpleasant or not good. We've got some bad news for you. The weather's too bad to go sailing. There's a bad smell in here. I'm in a really bad mood. Poor Shona. She's been having a bad time lately.
adjective Someone is bad at doing something when they can't do it very well. He's a really bad driver. I've always been bad at maths.
adjective Something is bad for you when it's harmful to your health. Smoking's bad for you.
adjective You say a pain is bad when it is very strong. I've got a bad pain in my stomach. Jan always gets bad headaches.
adjective When someone feels sick, they often say they feel bad.
adjective If you say you have a bad leg, heart, knee or any other part of your body, you mean it doesn't function properly. You shouldn't lift heavy weights if you've got a bad back.
adjective If someone is bad, their behaviour is hurtful or unhelpful to other people, or even evil. He may be bad, but putting him in jail will just make him worse. Bad girl, stop that!
adjective If an accident or natural disaster is bad, it's very serious. There have been some very bad bus crashes recently.
adjective Food is bad when it is spoiled or rotten. Another word word for this is off. I think this meat's gone badit smells funny.
adjective If you feel bad about something, you feel sorry, sad or ashamed about it. Don't feel bad about breaking that cupit was an accident.
not bad If someone says something is not bad, they mean it's quite good. 'How are you going?' 'Not bad.' This wine's not bad at all.

too bad When someone says that something is too bad, they mean it is a shame, but nothing can be done about it. It's too bad we couldn't get tickets for the concert. 'Silke's going to miss the train.' 'Too bad.'
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb badly He plays the flute really badly. The children behaved very badly. noun badness

form.definition: verb Bade is the past tense of meanings 2 and 3 of bid.

noun A badge is a plastic or metal disc or a paper label with words or a picture on it. People wear badges on their clothes to show support for a group, membership of an organisa~tion, or their rank or identity. People buy Legacy badges once a year to help the families of members of the armed forces who've died at war. Conference members can pick up their name badges at the office.

verb If you badger someone, you annoy them by constantly asking them questions or wanting them to do something. Stop badgering mego and ask someone else! She's always badgering me for money. His kids had been badgering him to take them to the cinema.
verb When you baffle someone, you confuse them. I'm baffled by all this jargon. Why can't they explain things clearly?

noun A bag is a container, often made of cloth, which you use for carrying or storing things. Be careful your purse doesn't fall out of your bag. I've packed my bag for the weekend. I bought three bags of groceries. Would you like a bag for that?
When you say you have bags of something, you mean you have lots of that thing. You have a great deal of it. 'Have we got enough cheese?' 'Yes, bags of it.'
noun Baggage is the suitcases, bags and boxes that belong to a traveller. Do you have any baggage to check in?
noun See Indonesian.
noun Bail is the money paid so that an arrested person can go free until their case is heard in court. He was let out on $4000 bail.
bail out (a) If you bail someone out, you help them out of a difficult situation. Madhu couldn't pay his bills, so I bailed him out by lending him some money.
(b) If you bail someone out of jail, you pay their bail. She was locked in a cell until her father came to bail her out.

(c) If you bail water out of a boat, or if you bail out a boat, you empty the water over the side using a bucket or other container. The boat started to leak water badly, so we had to bail it out to stay afloat.
noun Bait is food you put on a hook or in a trap to attract fish or animals so that you can catch them.

noun A bait is also a piece of food which has been poisoned. It is used to attract and kill animals that are pests. The farmer laid baits to poison the dingoes. You can buy cockroach baits in any supermarket.~[qr

dictionary.entry:
bakebEIk
1 verb You bake food by cooking it in an oven. 2 verb When you heat something to make it hard, you bake it. The bricks are baked in a large furnace.
... WORD FAMILY noun baker noun bakery (bakeries)

form.definition: noun Baking powder is put in bread and cakes to make them rise when they are baked.
noun Baking soda is the common name for sodium bicarbonate.
verb You balance something when you keep it in a steady position so that it doesn't fall or tip over. I balanced the bucket on the window ledge. Can you balance on one foot?
noun The balance in your bank account is the amount of money in it.
adjective If someone is balanced they consider all views before making a decision.
adjective If a report or argument is balanced, it pays equal attention to all views and opinions. Not one newspaper gave a balanced account of the events.
noun A balcony is a platform built out, above ground level, from the side of a building. It has a low wall or railing around it to stop you from falling off.
form.note: ... A SIMILAR WORDis veranda. See the picture at house.

form.definition: adjective If someone is bald, they have little or no hair on top of their head. Juan started going bald when he was only twenty.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun baldness

form.definition: noun A bale is a large amount of wool, paper, cotton or hay which is tied up tightly into a bundle.
noun A ball is a round object you use in certain games and sports. You can bounce, kick, roll, throw or catch a ball.
noun Some things that have a round shape are called balls. The Christmas tree was decorated with coloured glass balls. The cat was playing with a ball of string.
noun In informal language, balls are testicles. Using this word may ~offend some people. Jim kicked him in the balls.
noun A ball is an event where people wear formal evening clothes and dance, eat and drink.
balls In informal language, balls means nonsense. Using this word may offend some people. 'It'll only take a couple of hours.' 'Balls! It'll take several days, more like.'
have a ball In informal language, you say you are having a ball if you are having a very enjoyable time. We had a ball at Teri's birthday party!
on the ball (a) If you are on the ball, you are alert and can think and act quickly. As a pilot you have to be on the ball all the time. I'm sorry, I'm not really on the ball today.

(b) You also say someone is on the ball if they are well informed and up-to-date with information. I can never tell him anything he doesn't already knowhe's so on the ball these days. It's important to keep on the ball with the latest technology.
play ball If you are willing to play ball, you agree to cooperate or to do what someone else wants you to do. We only wanted Mei to give us some advice but she wouldn't play ball.
start or keep the ball rolling If you start or keep the ball rolling, you begin or continue to do something. The auctioneer said: 'Who'll start the ball rolling by making a bid?'

the ball is in your court When someone tells you that the ball is in your court, they are telling you that it is now your turn to take action. I sent my form back to the manager, so the ball's in his court now.
whole new ball game If you say a situation is a whole new ball game, you tion from the one you have known before. Computing these days is a whole new ball game compared to ten years ago.
noun Ballast is the heavy material carried by ships to keep them stable, or by hot air balloons to control how high they fly. Ballast is usually sand, water, iron or broken stones.
noun A ballet is a performance by a group of professional dancers who act out a story to music using no speech or singing.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective ballet ...ballet dancers.

form.definition: noun A balloon is a brightly coloured tube of thin rubber that you make bigger by blowing air or gas into it. You use balloons as toys or decorations. Blowing up all those balloons for your party has worn me out!
noun A balloon is also a large bag that is filled with hot air or gas to~[qr

dictionary.entry:
[xthead,ballotmake it rise and float in the sky. ally have a basket attached below them to carry passengers. Another expression for this is hot air balloon.[xthead,ballot--ballot`bAl@t
noun A ballot is the process of Our new union officials were elected by a secret ballot.

form.definition: noun A ballpoint pen is a pen which has, as its point, a small ball bearing which rolls ink from a cartridge onto the page.
form.note: ... OTHER WORDSfor this are ballpoint and biro.

dictionary.entry: balmy`ba:mi:balmierbalmiest adjective You say the weather is balmy when it is mild and warm. It's nice to sit on the deck with a cool drink on these balmy evenings.

form.definition: verb If you bamboozle someone, you confuse or trick them. I get bamboozled by these video recordersthere are so many buttons to push. Don't let her bamboozle you into staying.

dictionary.entry:
banbAnbansbannedbanning 1 verb If someone bans something, they forbid people to see, read, use or do it. Another word for
noun A ban is an official order forbidding you to do something. The ban on nuclear ships was lifted. The airlines have put a ban on smoking in planes.

form.definition: noun A band is a group of people who have gathered together. A band of protesters was waiting outside Parliament House.
noun A band is a group of musicians who play military, jazz, pop or rock music.
noun A band is a narrow strip of material. My hat band is made of snake skin. She had her hair tied back with a pink silk band.[qr
noun A bandage is a long strip of [xthead,bandagecloth, usually cotton, that you use to wrap around a wound.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb bandage Her leg was heavily bandaged.[qr

dictionary.entry:
bandaid`bAndEId
noun A bandaid is a light covering that you stick over a surface wound to protect it while it's healing.

form.definition: noun A bandicoot is a small rat-like Australian marsupial.
noun A bandit is a robber, especially one who is armed and violent.
noun A bang is a sudden loud exploding noise. The balloon burst with a loud bang. She slammed the book down on the desk with a bang. There was a loud bang and he slumped forwards.
verb If you bang part of your body, you hit it accidentally against something. Watch out! Don't bang your head on that bar.
verb If you bang something, you hit it, or close it, making a loud noise. Please don't bang the door when you leave. I could hear her banging around upstairs.
with a bang If you say something goes off with a bang, you mean it has been a great success. The barbecue went off with a bang, and I could hardly get them to go home!
noun A banjo is a musical instrument with four or more strings to pluck, a long neck and a round body like a drum.
noun A bank is a company which keeps your money safe for you, invests it and lends money at interest.
verb If you bank your money, it in a bank. Most shop owners bank their money at the end of every day.

noun A bank is a place where things are stored until they are ready to be used. There are various kinds of banks; for example, there are blood banks and data banks, as well as banks which handle your money.
noun A bank is the raised sloping land along the side of a river or lake.
noun A bank is a mound of sand, mud, snow or earth. People were standing on the grass bank, watching the hockey match.
noun A bank of clouds is a large mass of clouds. A large bank of black clouds gathered, and then the rain began.
noun A bank is a row or line of anything. A bank of lights lit the scene of the accident.
bank on If you bank on something, you can depend or rely on it. We can bank on Jackie to give us a hand. ~ ... WORD FAMILY noun banker
adjective A person or business is bankrupt when they can't pay their debts. Many small businesses have gone bankrupt because of the high interest rates.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bankruptcy (bankruptcies) The company was forced into bankruptcy.

form.definition: noun A banksia is an Australian shrub with thick leaves and tiny flowers packed together in the shape of a brush.[qr

dictionary.entry:
banner`bAn@
noun A banner is a long flag with messages or slogans on it. You often see banners stretched between poles or across a street. We stuck a banner over our driveway, saying 'Welcome home, Anna'.

form.definition: noun A banquet is a large formal dinner usually held in honour of someone or for a special occasion.
noun A baptism is a Christian religious ceremony in which someone is sprinkled with water or put under water to show they have become a member of the church.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is christening. ... WORD FAMILY verb baptise (<or> baptize)

form.definition: verb If you bar someone, you forbid them to go to a place or to do something. Children under 18 are barred from this area at night. The workers were barred from striking while the case was being heard.
noun A bar is a long straight piece of metal. Bars are often put across windows, doors or gates to stop people from entering or leaving. He was beaten with an iron bar.

noun A bar is a rectangular block of any hard material. I'll buy us a bar of chocolate. ...a bar of soap. ...a gold bar. 4a noun A bar is the counter in a pub or club where you can buy alcoholic drinks. He was standing at the bar.
noun A bar is also the room in a pub or club where you can drink alcoholic drinks. I'll meet you in the front bar after work.
noun A bar is any place where you can buy a particular type of food or drink. Can you pick up a loaf of bread at the milk bar? ...a sandwich bar. ...a snack bar. ...a wine bar.
noun A barb is a sharp backward-facing point on fish hooks and arrow heads. It stops the hook or arrow from being easily pulled out.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective barbed ...barbed wire.

form.definition: noun A barbarian is someone who is cruel and uncivilised.
noun We say someone is a barbarian if they are rude and act in a way that offends other people.
noun A barbecue is a structure in which you can build a fire for cooking meat out of doors.
noun A barbecue is also an outdoor party or meal where you serve food cooked on a barbecue. A short form of this is barby or barbie (/babi/).
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGof this is barbeque. Sometimes it is shortened to versions like BBQ orBar-B-Q. ... WORD FAMILY verb barbecue Could you barbecue the steaks while I get the salad ready?

form.definition: noun A barber is a person who cuts men's hair.
noun A barbiturate is a drug doctors sometimes advise their patients to take to help them relax or sleep.

noun A bar code is a printed code which looks like a series of vertical bars of different widths. Most items you buy have a bar code printed on them which a computer-controlled cash register can use to identify them and enter their price.
adjective Something is bare when it is not covered by anything. The sand was hot on my bare feet. The wind whistled in the bare branches.
adjective A cupboard or room is bare when it is empty. Our fridge is usually bare by Friday.
adjective Something is bare when nothing has been added, or when it is plain and simple. Don't give me excuses, just give me the bare facts. Please keep conversation to the bare minimum.

adverb You use barely to mean that something is only just so. He's earning barely enough to live on. This is a bad lineI can barely hear you. By the time they found her she was barely alive. I'd barely got back home when she rang me.
noun A bargain is something you buy at a low price and which you think is good value for the money you paid for it. You can get some great bargains at the January sales.
noun A bargain is an agreement you make with someone when you promise to do something if they will do something for you. I'll make a bargain with you: I'll do the washing-up if you do the cooking.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb bargain They bargained over who would do which task.

form.definition: verb If you barge into or through something, you push into it quickly in a rude and rough way. The police barged through the crowd. 2 noun A barge is a large flat-bottomed river boat which is used to carry very heavy loads.
barge in If you barge in you interrupt someone while they are talking or doing something. Do you always barge in without knocking like that?
noun A baritone is a male singer with a medium-deep voice, between tenor and bass voices in pitch.
noun A bark is the sound a dog makes.
noun The bark of a tree is its outer covering.
bark at If you bark at someone, you shout at them in a sharp, loud voice.

barking up the wrong tree If someone says that you are barking up the wrong tree, they mean you are wrong in what you think will happen. If you think I'll let you have my car this weekend, you're barking up the wrong tree.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb bark Your dog is always barking.

form.definition: noun A barn is a farm building where you keep animals, or where you store hay and other animal food.
noun A barometer is an instrument you use to measure the air pressure so you can see if the weather will change.
verb If you barrack for someone, especially when they are playing sport, you shout words of encouragement to them. Which team do you barrack forCarlton or Collingwood?
verb If you barrack someone, especially when they are playing sport, you jeer at them to make them feel uncomfortable. A small group at the back persistently barracked the speaker.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun barracking

form.definition: noun A barracks is the building or group of buildings where soldiers live and work.

noun A barrage is a long and heavy attack from a set of guns. You can also describe an attack of words as a barrage. After the Budget speech, the Treasurer faced a barrage of questions from the press. The advancing army was held back by a barrage of cannon fire.
noun A barrel is a large round container usually made from strips of wood and which is used to store beer or wine.
noun A barrel is also the metal tube of a gun through which the bullet is fired.

over a barrel When someone says they have you over a barrel, they mean you've got no choice but to do what they want. You've got me over a barrel. I don't want to pay that price but my petrol tank is empty and I need to get home.
adjective You say the land or soil is barren when it is so poor it cannot produce crops.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is infertile.

form.definition: noun A barrier is a fence or wall which keeps people or things from moving from one area to another. The Berlin Wall was a barrier between East and West Germany for more than 30 years. Show your tickets at the barrier.
noun A barrier is also anything which stops something from happening. Not knowing English is a barrier to getting a good job in Australia.
noun A barrister is a lawyer who presents cases in court.
form.note: ... COMPAREthis with solicitor.

form.definition: noun A barrow is a small cart on which you can stack things to move them from place to place. You can often buy fruit and other goods from barrows parked in city streets.
noun The base of something is its lowest edge or part, especially the part on which the rest stands. We looked up from the base of the cliff to the climbers at the top. ...the base of the vase.
noun A base is a defended and protected centre used by an army, navy or air force. The US has military bases all over the world.
noun A base is also the main centre from which an organisation is controlled. Our company's base is in Sydney, but we have branches all over Australia. ~

noun The base of something is its main element or ingredient. From this, a mixture or something new is made. This sauce has a tomato base. The base of his argument is that the price of oil is too high.
verb If you base one thing on another, you develop it from an earlier form or idea. The novel was based on a true story.
noun Baseball is a game played with a bat and ball by two teams of nine players. It is popular in the United States and in Japan.
noun The basement of a building is the room or area below ground level. Where's the car park? Is it in the basement?
verb If you bash someone or something, you hit them very hard. He was bashed by a gang of youths.
noun A bash, in informal language, is a big party. Karma is putting on a bash at the social club next week.

give it a bash In informal language, if you say you give something a bash, you mean you try to do it. A similar expression is have a bash. I've never used a computer before, but I'll give it a bash. Why don't you have a bash at doing it yourself now?
adjective You say someone is bashful if they are shy and don't know what to say or do when they are with other people.

adjective You say something is basic if it is simple and has no unnecessary things added. Our motel room was very basic, but clean and cheap. High interest rates are forcing people to move from luxury houses into more basic accommodation.
adjective You say something is basic if it is the main or most important thing on which other things depend, rest or are built. The basic ingredient of an omelette is eggs.

basics The basics of a subject or process are those things which are the simplest and most important aspects of it. If we're going to solve our economic problems, we'll have to go back to basics. The basics of a good education are reading, writing and arithmetic.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb basically

form.definition: noun A basin is a container, usually round, which is wider at the top than the bottom and not very deep. You use it to hold liquids in.
noun A basin is the sink in a bathroom or toilet. Another word for this is washbasin.

noun The basis of something is its most important part which supports it and gives it its structure. This book was the basis for his new film. The family is no longer the basis of our society. ...the basis of your argument.
noun The basis of something is its main part or ingredient. Chicken stock is the basis for many good soups.
noun If you do something on a particular basis, you do it in that way or under those conditions. Jan worked there on a part-time basis. The DSS decides who gets benefits on a case-by-case basis.
verb You bask in something if you let yourself enjoy the pleasant feeling it gives you. Cats love to bask in the sun. I basked in the compliments I received after my talk.
noun A basket is a container made of thin strips of cane or plastic woven into a firm shape. It is used for carrying or storing things. Put it in the wastepaper basket. ...a shopping basket.
noun Basketball is an indoor game played by two teams of five or six players. Each team tries to score points by throwing a large ball through a basket on the top of a pole at each end of the court.
noun A bass is a singer with the lowest range of the male voice.
adjective A bass guitar, drum or other musical instrument is one which makes a deep sound.
noun The bass is the lowest tone in a musical chord, or the lowest part in a composition.
noun A bassinette is a baby's bed shaped like a basket.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is bassinet.

form.definition: noun You call someone a bastard if you think they are mean or cruel, or if you just want to insult them. The word is usually only used to refer to a man, and is very insulting when used in this way. I left my old job because the foreman was a real bastard. I'll get you, you bastard!

noun You call something a bastard if it is unpleasant or very difficult to do. When the word is used in this way it may offend some people. The weather was a real bastard. Dirty ovens can be bastards to clean. The maths exam was a real bastard.

noun You can also use bastard in a non-offensive way to ~address good friends of yours. You should only use the word in this way with people you know very well and if you are sure they won't be offended. Come on you bastards, let's get this show on the road! Gosh, you're a lucky bastard!
noun In old-fashioned language, when you say a person is a bastard, you mean their birth was illegitimate because when they were born their parents weren't married.[qr

dictionary.entry:
batbAtbatsbattedbatting
noun A bat is the wooden stick or club you use to hit the ball with when you play games like baseball, cricket and table tennis.
verb If you bat, you have a turn at hitting the ball with a bat. Who's batting now? Whose turn is it to bat?
noun A bat is a small mouse-like animal with large leathery wings. Bats are blind, fly at night and eat fruit or insects.
noun A bat is a thick rectangular sheet of fibrous material you put in the roof to insulate your house and keep it cool in summer and warm in winter. Another spelling for this is batt.
not bat an eyelid or an eye If you don't bat an eyelid or an eye, you show no surprise or feeling. He didn't bat an eyelid when he was told his car had been stolen.
off your own bat If you do something off your own bat, you do it on your own without any help, or without being told to do it. Did you organise the whole thing off your own bat?

form.definition: noun A batch is a number of things made at the same time. The manufacturer is recalling all tins marked Batch 4309J.
noun A batch is also a group of people or things of the same kind. People were admitted into the exhibition in batches of ten. ...a batch of letters to post.

noun A bath is a long deep basin which you fill with water and sit in while you wash yourself. Another word for this is bathtub. After working hard all day, it's nice to be able to lie back and relax in a nice hot bath.
noun If ~you have or take a bath, you wash yourself or relax in a bath. Karel had a bath before going to bed.

verb When you bathe you have a bath or you wash yourself. You can also bathe only part of your body, especially if it's injured. It's wise to bathe at least once a day in hot weather. You should bathe that cut on your foot before it gets infected.
verb In old-fashioned or official language, when you bathe, you go for a swim.
noun Bathers is a rather old-fashioned word for the costume you wear when you go swimming.
form.note: ... OTHER WORDSfor this are swimmers and cossie.

form.definition: noun The bathroom in your house is the room which has the bath or shower in it.
noun A baton is a short thin stick which the conductor of an orchestra or choir beats in the air to show the rhythm of the music.
noun A baton is the short thick stick that is passed from one runner to the next in a relay race.
noun A baton is a short heavy club carried by a police officer and used for protection or as a weapon. Another word for this is truncheon.
noun A battalion is a large unit of soldiers that is made up of three or four smaller groups called companies.
noun A batten is a strip of wood you use to strengthen something or fasten something to.

batten down (the hatches) If you say you are going to batten down or batten down the hatches, you mean you are preparing for a difficult time or an approaching disaster, as sailors fasten down openings or hatches on deck before a storm hits.
verb If you batter something, you hit it over and over again so that it becomes badly damaged or injured. Huge waves battered the wreck until it sank below the sea.

noun Batter is a mixture of flour, milk and eggs you use to cover fish and meat before you fry them in oil. b verb When you batter food, you cover it with a coating of flour, herbs, egg and milk. ...battered onion rings.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun battering The house took a battering in the storm.[qr

dictionary.entry:
battery/btri, -tri/ (plural form\optima0\batteries
noun A battery is a cell or group of cells used to store or produce electricity.
noun A battery is a long line of small cages in which chickens or other animals are kept. Many people don't like buying eggs that are laid by hens kept in batteries. They buy free-range eggs instead.

form.definition: noun A battle is a large military action, usually as part of a war between countries. b noun A battle is any difficult fight or struggle in which you try to achieve something. Anne had a five-year battle with cancer before she died. ...the battle of the sexes.
battle of wits If you have a battle of wits with someone, you have a contest with them to see who is smarter.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb battle She's battling the pressures of poverty. ...battling with his homework.

form.definition: verb If you baulk at something, you suddenly become very unwilling to do it or to accept it. She was going to buy it at first, but then she baulked at the price.
adjective You say a piece of writing is bawdy when it has sexual jokes in it which could offend some people. Footballers love to sing bawdy songs. ...a bawdy poem.
verb If you bawl something, you shout it in a very loud rough way. The sergeant bawled a quick order, and the advance began.
verb A child bawls when it cries noisily.
bawl someone out If you bawl someone out, you speak to them in a loud angry voice because they have done something wrong. The boss will bawl you out if you're late again.
bawl your eyes out If you bawl your eyes out, you cry uncontrollably.

noun A bay is a sheltered part of a sea or lake which is enclosed or surrounded by a curved shore. See the picture at seashore. We sheltered from the storm in a quiet bay with two other yachts. ...Botany Bay.
noun A bay is a small space or area separated from a larger area by a wall or barrier. The truck backed into the loading bay. ...a parking bay. ...the school's sick bay.
verb When a dog or wolf bays, it makes a ~long deep howling sound.

keep or hold at bay If you keep something or someone at bay or hold them at bay, you make sure they don't come too close to you. Fernando kept the dog at bay with a long stick. I earn enough to keep poverty at bay.
noun A bayonet is a long sharp knife that can be attached to the end of a soldier's rifle.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb bayonet

form.definition: abbreviation for barbecue.

abbreviation for before (the birth of) Christ. You use BC in dates to show the number of years before the birth of Jesus Christ. The Great Pyramids of Egypt date back to 3000 BC. Alexander the Great lived in the 4th century BC.
form.note: ... NOTEAD is the abbreviation that indicates dates after the birth of Jesus. Notice that although BC is written after the date, AD is written before it.

form.definition: The verb to be is used as an auxiliary verb in English with a variety of functions.
verb It assists in creating continuous verb forms. I am going now. They were looking for you.
verb It is also used to form the passive voice of some verbs. She was sacked from her job. We've been asked to help.
verb It is used with an infinitive verb to indicate what must happen. This is a rather formal use. I don't care what they want, they are to go home immediately.
verb It can be used to connect the subject of a sentence with its complement. My name is Teri. This is the way to go. It was a pity you had to go. The fact that you like him is no excuse.
verb The verb be is used as an imperative to give a command or offer advice. Be a sport and give me a hand. Don't be silly!

noun A beach is the sandy or pebbly shore at the edge of a sea, lake or river. Australia is famous for its many clean sandy beaches. 2a verb When you beach a boat, you drive or pull it up onto the beach from the water. They quickly beached the boat before the storm arrived. We beached in the small cove early that morning. b verb When a whale beaches itself, it swims in to the shore with the tide and remains stranded on the beach when the tide goes back out.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective beached There were eight beached whales at Hervey Bay last week.

form.definition: noun A beach inspector is someone who patrols a surfing beach to make sure that people behave and dress properly. They also act as lifesavers.
noun A beacon is a light or radio signal which shows the way or gives a warning of danger, especially to ships or planes.
noun A bead is a small ball of coloured glass, plastic or wood with a hole through it. You can thread beads onto a piece of string or wire to make a necklace or bracelet.
noun A bead is a small drop of liquid. I saw beads of sweat on his upper lip.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective beady The rat had beady little eyes.

form.definition: noun A beak is the hard horny part of a bird's mouth.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is bill.

form.definition: noun A beam is a long heavy piece of wood, metal or concrete that supports the roof or walls of a building.

noun A beam is the line or ray of light or energy that goes out from the sun or from a torch or other device. A sudden beam of sunlight pierced the gloom. I accidentally broke the security beam and the burglar alarm went off. ...a laser beam.
verb If something beams, it sends out rays of light. Every morning the sun beams into my bedroom.
noun The beam of a ship is its widest part. Old sailing ships were very broad in the beam.
noun A beam is a radio or TV signal sent out in one direction.
verb If you beam at someone, you have a broad and happy smile on your face. The doctor walked quickly into the ward, beaming at the patients.

off beam In informal language, you say someone is off beam if you think they are wrong or mistaken. The press tried to predict what would be in the budget, but they were way off beam, as usual.~[xp\start\[ap--bean

noun A bean is a climbing plant which has smooth seeds growing in a long pod. The seeds of this plant are also called beans. You can eat the whole pod or just the seeds, depending on the type of bean. Our next door neighbour grows beans in his backyard. ...green beans. ...baked beans.

noun A bean is also the seed of a number of other plants, some of which we use to make drinks or oils. Coffee tastes best when it's made from freshly-ground coffee beans. ...cocoa beans. ...soya beans.

full of beans If you say someone is full of beans, you mean they are lively and energetic. The kids were suddenly full of beans when we told them we were going to the pictures. I was exhausted, but she was still full of beans.
spill the beans When someone spills the beans, they tell a secret too soon or to the wrong person. We're giving Peter a surprise birthday party, so don't spoil it by spilling the beans!
verb In formal language, if you say you bear something, you mean you carry it from one place to another. My grandparents arrived from Europe bearing gifts for the whole family.
verb If something can bear the weight of something else, then it can support or take that weight. I hope the ice can bear our weight.
verb If something or someone bears a particular mark, sign or characteristic, they have or show that characteristic. He bore no resemblance to his father. This bank cheque bears no signature.
verb If a woman bears a child, she gives birth to it. My grandmother bore eight childrenit was quite usual in those days. This cow has borne three champion calves in the last three seasons.
form.note: ... NOTE comes from an older spelling of borne.

form.definition: verb When a tree or plant bears fruit or leaves, it produces them as part of its growing. We extend this idea by saying that someone's efforts bear fruit when we mean that their efforts are successful. Gum trees bear leaves all year round.

verb If you bear a difficult situation, you suffer under it or you have to try to accept it. Young families with children are bearing the brunt of the recession. Carlos bore the main burden of his mother's death, because there was no-one else to look after the children.
verb If you can't bear something or someone, you can't tolerate them or be patient any longer. I can't bear listening to this music any more. He couldn't bear the thought of being alone.
verb If someone tells you to bear right or left, they are telling you to turn in that direction. Go down the road for about two kilometres, then bear left where the road forks.

bear down on or \optima,0,\ upon If something bears down on you, it comes towards you very quickly and is a danger to you. We turned and saw a big ship bearing down on our tiny boat. Lucy spotted me from across the yard and bore down on me.
bear in mind When you bear something in mind, you remember it and take it into consideration. Before you criticise him, bear in mind he's only new in this job.
bear out If something bears you out, it supports or proves what you believe or say. The evidence bears out what the doctors say. The young boy's story was borne out by his sister.

bear up If you bear up when something unpleasant happens, you stay cheerful and brave and you keep going in spite of the difficulties. Jackie doesn't bear up under pressure at all, but gets more and more nervous. My old car bore up very well during our trip around Australia.
bear with If someone asks you to bear with them, they are asking you to be patient. Please bear with me while I try to explain how this works.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective bearable The heat is hardly bearable. noun bearer She was the bearer of good news.

form.definition: noun A beard is the hair that grows on a man's cheeks and chin.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body. ... WORD FAMILY adjective bearded

form.definition: noun A bearing in a machine is a part which supports other parts which move or rotate around it. There's a problem with the washing machine. I think the bearings in the motor are gone.

noun A bearing is a direction or position as shown by a compass. The navigator took a compass bearing, then the yacht suddenly shifted course. I lost my bearings in the dark and ended up in the wrong street.
noun A person's bearing is the way in which they move, stand or behave. I could tell from his bearing that he'd had bad news. Her whole bearing conveys self-importance.
noun A beast is any animal, especially a wild animal with four legs. Because a donkey can carry heavy loads, it is used as a beast of burden in many countries.

dictionary.entry:
beatbi:tbeatsbeatbeatenbeating 1 verb If you beat something or someone, you hit them hard over and over again. I'll beat the mat to get rid of all the dust. I just love to hear the rain beating on the roof, don't you? As a child she
verb If you beat someone in a race, contest or game, you do better than they do in it. You defeat them. I could never beat my brother at chess.
verb If you beat someone to a place, you get there before them. Maria always beats me to the office and grabs the best parking space.
verb If you say that something beats something else, you mean it is better. A trip through Nepal sure beats a week in Melbourne. Go for it! 3a verb If you say, in informal language, that something beats you, you mean that it's too difficult for you to understand. It beats me how she always manages to find the best bargains. All this jargon beats me.
verb If you try to beat a difficulty, you do everything you can to overcome it. My sister tried everything to beat her arthritis. I'll beat this problem if it's the last thing I do! Beat the winter blues by spending July in Kakadu! 4a verb If something beats, it makes movements in a regular rhythm. Your heart should beat about 70 times a minute.
verb If you beat eggs or cream, you mix them with regular quick movements using a fork or whisk. Beat the egg whites until stiff, then fold in the sugar.
noun The beat of a piece of music is its main rhythm. Rock music always has a strong regular beat.
verb If you beat the rhythm of something, especially music, you mark the timing of it by moving your hand or tapping your foot.
noun A beat is the regular path or route someone takes in the course of their work or daily routine. Local shop owners asked for more police on the beat around the shopping centre.
adjective In informal language, when someone says they're beat, they mean they are very tired. Another word for this is bushed. Gosh, I'm beat after all that Christmas shopping!
beat about the bush If you beat about the bush, you talk about lots of other things and you don't get to the point of what you're trying to say. I wish you'd just tell me what you want and stop beating about the bush.
9 beat down (a) If you beat someone down when they're trying to sell you something, you get them to accept a lower price. I got a good deal on that carI beat the dealer down by $2,000! (b) When one of the forces of nature, such as rain, hail, or sun, beats down, it is very strong and intense. The midday sun beat down, softening the bitumen. The rain kept beating down for hours, turning creeks into raging rivers.
beat it If someone tells you to beat it, they're telling you, in an insulting way, to go away. He told his little brother to beat it.
beat off If you beat off an attack or attacker, you fight them so that they leave you alone. An elderly woman beat off a mugger with her walking stick this morning.
beat up If you beat someone up, you attack and hurt them by hitting or beating them. Ali's a bully, but he was finally beaten up when he had a go at someone his own size.
... WORD FAMILY noun beating I gave the mat a good beating.

form.definition: adjective In informal language, you say someone or something is beaut when they are fine, good or enjoyable. I think she's beaut. We had a beaut day on Sunday. Tony has a beaut motorbike.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun beaut She's a beaut!

form.definition: noun A beautician is someone whose job is to advise women on buying and using cosmetics and other beauty treatments.

adjective You say someone or something is beautiful when you find them attractive and enjoyable to look at, hear, taste, smell or feel. What a beautiful baby! We had beautiful weather on our holidays. Mozart wrote some of the most beautiful music ever heard.
adjective You can say something is beautiful if it is done or carried out extremely well. They scored a beautiful goal just two minutes before full time. ...beautiful singing.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb beautifully

form.definition: noun Beauty is that quality in someone or something which gives you great pleasure to see or hear them. The beauty of the Snowy Mountains is impossible to describe. ...famous for her beauty. ...the beauty of her voice.
noun A woman can be called a beauty if she is beautiful. My mother was a great beauty when she was young.
noun A beauty is a particularly good example of something. My new camera is a real beauty. That bruise you've got on your arm is a beauty, isn't it?

noun The beauty of something is the feature that makes it better than other similar things. One of the beauties of this house is its closeness to the station. The beauty of this dictionary is that it's easy to understand.

interjection In informal language, when someone says beauty!, they are expressing their pleasure and delight at something. Another expression for this is you beaut!. 'Would you like to go out for tea?' 'Beauty!' Beauty! I passed all my exams.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See beautiful.

form.definition: verb Became is the past tense of become.
conjunction You use because when you want to give the reason for something. I did it because I was angry. We went to the beach because it was hot.
verb If you beckon to someone, you signal or wave to them to come over to you. The tour guide beckoned to her group, who obediently followed her.

verb When someone or something becomes something else, they change in that direction. It takes six years to become a doctor. The dog became angry and started to growl. I became thirsty working in the garden. 2 become of You ask what has become of someone, or what will become of them, when you don't know what happened or will happen to them. I wonder what became of that nice girl from next door? What will become of you if you don't take your homework seriously?

adjective In formal, rather old-fashioned language, you say a piece of clothing or other article of fashion is becoming when you mean it suits someone or makes them look good. Those shoes look very becoming on you.
noun A bed is a place where you can sleep, especially the piece of furniture with a mattress, pillow, sheets and blankets. I never go to bed before 11:00 p.m. Get your dirty shoes off the bed.
noun A bed is a part of the garden which you have prepared for growing flowers or vegetables. We'll have to do another garden bed for next season's tomatoes. ...a flower bed.
noun A river bed or a sea bed is the land underneath the water. The oil drilling platform is anchored to the sea bed. We were desperate for water, but all we could find was a dry river bed.
noun A bed is also a foundation or base on which something is built. Before we build a garage, we'll first lay down a bed of concrete. The meat is served on a bed of rice.
go to bed with To go to bed with someone can mean to have sex with them.
noun Bedding is the sheets, pillowcases and blankets you put on a bed to make it ready to sleep on.
adjective You say something is bedraggled when it is limp, wet and dirty. After spending the night out in the rain, the dog came in looking sorry and bedraggled.
adjective You say someone is bedridden when they are too sick or weak to get out of bed. My back was so bad I was bedridden for three weeks.
noun A bedroom is the room where you sleep.
noun A bee is a stinging insect that lives in a hive and makes honey.
noun A bee, usually called a working bee, is a group effort to complete a task. The whole neighbourhood turned up for the working bee to clean up the school playground.

bee in your bonnet You say someone has a bee in their bonnet when they are so excited or worried about something that they can do nothing but talk about it all the time. She's got a real bee in her bonnet about the kids next door and their noisy habits.

noun Beef is the meat from cattle. On Sundays we always have roast beef for dinner. 2 noun In informal language, a beef is a complaint. Do you have any beefs about this new system? What's your beef, mate?
beef up If something needs to be beefed up, it needs to be made more exciting or strengthened in some way.
verb Been is the past participle of be.
noun Beer is a type of alcoholic drink made from malted grain.
noun A beer is a glass, a bottle or a can of beer. There's nothing like a couple of icy cold beers on a hot day!
conjunction If one thing happens before another does, it happens earlier. Marie arrived just before I left. You should wash your hands before you touch the food. He was married before he was twenty.

preposition If something happens before a particular time, it happens earlier than that time. I'd like to get there before Monday. We won't arrive before eleven now. Can you deliver it before Christmas?

adverb If you've done something before or it has happened before, you've done it or it has happened sometime in the past. I've never done this beforeI hope it works! The fuse blew once before, but we got it fixed.
preposition In formal language, we say that something is before something else if it is in front of it. His statue stands before the castle.

verb If you befriend someone, you become a friend to them. You treat them kindly and look after them. I didn't know what to expect, but a woman on the plane befriended me and told me all about Perth. We befriended the stray dog and took it home with us.
verb If you beg someone to do something, you plead with them and ask them to do it as a great favour. Rosita kept begging her mother to buy her a bike for Christmas.
verb When someone begs, they ask people to give them food or money to live on. It's terrible to see people begging in the streets.
go begging We say something is going begging if no one wants it. If that stapler's going begging, I'll take it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun beggar

form.definition: verb Began is the past tense of begin.
verb When something begins, it starts at a certain time. When did you begin working here? World War II began in 1939. The concert begins at 8 p.m. Where shall I begin? Are you ready for me to begin?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun beginning The beginning of the play was the most disappointing part.

form.definition: noun A beginner is someone who has just started to learn something. I can't play the flute very wellI'm just a beginner.

verb If you begrudge someone something, you are not happy to see them have it, perhaps because you think you should have it yourself. Lakshmi begrudged her sister her good looks. We really shouldn't begrudge him winning Lottohe deserves a bit of luck.
verb Begun is the past participle of begin.

dictionary.entry: behalfb@`ha:f noun; in the phrase on behalf If you do something on someone's behalf or on behalf of someone, you do it as their representative. On behalf of the staff, I would like to wish you all the best in the future. I can't make it to the meeting tonight, so would you speak on my behalf?

form.definition: verb If you behave in a certain way, you act in that way. Even though he's only ten, he behaves like an adult. Our cat has been behaving strangely these last few days. This boat generally behaves extremely well.

verb If you behave yourself or behave, you act in the way you should, or do what you're supposed to do. The opposite of this is misbehave. I'm afraid our children never behave themselves for visitors. This car had better behave itself today, or I'm going to sell it. Stop it now! Behave!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun behaviour (<or> behavior) His behaviour seemed weird to me.

form.definition: preposition If something is behind something else, it is at the back of it where it often can't be seen from the other side. My shoes are behind the door. In this photo, Sue's the one standing behind Benjie.
preposition If something goes behind something else, it goes to the back of it and maybe can't be seen from the front. The moon went behind a cloud.
preposition If something is behind you, it is not in the direction you are facing, so that you have to turn around to see it. I'm sure I heard someone behind me.

preposition If someone is behind an idea or a project, they are supporting it or responsible for it. The Prime Minister is fully behind the push for a republic. I wonder who's behind the move to replace him?
preposition The events or facts behind a particular situation are the ones that have caused it. You'll never discover what was behind his resignation.
adverb If someone is behind, they are not keeping up with their schedule or they have been delayed. Mario was always behind with his assignments because he had two jobs.

preposition If you are behind someone else, you are not as advanced as they are or you are not doing as well as they are in a race or competition. He's always behind his brother when the school reports come home. We're not far behind you on the competition table.
adjective Something that is beige in colour is a very pale brown, like the colour of natural wool.
noun A being is something that lives, either real or imagined. The only thing the island lacked was the presence of another human being. ...alien beings from outer space.
come into being When something comes into being, it is born or starts to exist. How did this dictionary come into being? Australia, as a nation, came into being in 1901.
adjective Something is belated if it is delayed, and comes later than it should. I completely forgot Quang's birthday, but I sent him a belated card.
verb When you belch, you make a loud noise in your throat as gas from your stomach comes out through your mouth. In Australia it's not polite to belch after eating or drinking.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is burp.

form.definition: noun A belief is an idea, thought or feeling that you accept as true, good and real. It's my belief that children should have as broad an education as possible. ...religious beliefs. ...political beliefs.
noun Belief in someone or something is a trust that they won't let you down. Her belief in her husband's ability is amazing. ...belief in God.

verb If you believe something, you think it is true and correct. If you believe someone, you think they are telling the truth. Which version do you believe? Leyla believes that this medicine will cure her. Don't believe hershe's a born liar. It was a difficult job, believe me!

verb You can say you believe something instead of saying that you know it, when you recognise the possibility that you may be wrong. She's gone home, I believe. I believe he's gone to live in Darwin, but you'd better check to make sure.
believe in (a) If you believe in something or someone, you have faith or trust in them. I believe in regular doses of vitamin C. It's important to have a teacher you can believe in.
(b) You say you believe in something if you are sure that it exists, although you have no definite proof. Do you believe in ghosts?
form.note: ... NOTEThis word is not normally used in its continuous form. We say I believe, not I am believing. ... WORD FAMILY adjective believable Her story is quite believable.noun believer Francine is a great believer in regular exercise.

form.definition: verb If you belittle someone or something, you say things that make them seem unimportant or you shame them without reason. You shouldn't belittle his effortshe's doing his best. My parents never missed an opportunity to belittle me.

noun A bell is a hollow cup-shaped object, usually made of metal, which makes a ringing sound when you strike it. Anything designed to make a similar sound can also be called a bell. The church bells began to ring as soon as the wedding was over. Ring the door bell when you arrive.
ring a bell If something rings a bell with you, it reminds you of something that you had forgotten. The picture on this postcard rings a bell. Didn't we go there once?

adjective If a person or a country is belligerent, they are aggressive and eager to quarrel or fight. Sandy's always so belligerent when you criticise him. Most stabbings are done by belligerent young males.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun belligerence His belligerence with other students made him unpopular.

form.definition: verb If you bellow, you shout in a very loud deep voice. Even from the other side of the river, I could hear the sergeant bellow orders to the cadets.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bellowing His constant bellowing is giving me a headache.

form.definition: noun Belly is an informal word for the front part of your body that contains your stomach. A big belly is often the mark of a beer drinker.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is abdomen, which is more formal or medical in use.

form.definition: noun In children's language, your bellybutton is your navel.

verb If someone or something belongs in a certain place, that is the place where they are usually found or live or where they should be. Put your toys back in the box where they belong. It took me a long time to feel I really belonged in Australia.
belong to (a) If something belongs to you, you own it. That black cat belongs to my sister. Who does this jumper belong to?
(b) If you belong to a club, organisation or any other group or category, you are a member of it. Do you belong to any political party? Richard belongs to the city branch of Rotary.
noun Your belongings are things you own. Nick was carrying all his belongings in a bag over his shoulder. Please don't leave your belongings in these lockers overnight.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is possessions.

form.definition: adjective In formal language, you say someone or something is beloved when they are greatly loved and admired. She kept many photos to remind her of her beloved family back home in Italy. Timmy refused to be parted from his beloved toy train. ...the nation's beloved leader.
adverb Something that is below is lower in position. From the lookout, I could see the city lights spread out below.

preposition Something is below something else if it is lower than it, in position or rank or amount. The sun is just below the horizon now. He's not bottom of the classthere are two others below him. We're selling these bargains below cost.
adverb If you say something is below when you are writing, you mean it is lower down the page or on a later page. See the illustration below.
noun A belt is a band of material, especially leather, which you wear around your waist to hold your clothing in place. You can also wear a belt for decoration.
noun A belt is also a circular band used on machines to drive moving parts or to move things from one place to another. The engine got too hot when the car's fanbelt snapped.

noun A belt is a strip of land or an area where something special is grown or found. The state's wheat belt was suffering a long drought. A wide belt of trees joining the two forests would let koalas migrate with ease.
verb In informal language, if you say you belt someone, you mean you beat them very hard. My old teacher just loved to belt us if he caught us talking.
below the belt You say that something that's said or done is below the belt if you think it is unfair and hurtful. I must say bringing up his divorce was a bit below the belt.
belt out In informal language, you say that you belt out a song if you sing it in a very loud voice.
belt up (a) If someone tells you to belt up, they are telling you in a rude way to stop talking. If you don't belt up, I'll kick you out of here!
(b) In a car, to belt up means to fasten your seat belt.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun belting His father gave him a belting for coming home late.

form.definition: noun A bench is a wooden seat long enough for two or more people to sit on. She sat at one end of the park bench and he sat at the other.
noun A bench is a long heavy table for working at. My father was very fond of his old work bench in the garage.

noun The seats for certain important officials, such as members of parliament or judges, are often called benches. She proudly took her place on the government benches. The Chief Justice is on the bench this morning.

dictionary.entry:
bendbEndbendsbentbending 1a verb When you bend something, you change its shape or position from straight to round or angular. Yanica bent the coathanger to form a hook. Juan
verb When something bends, it changes its shape from straight to curved or it changes its direction. The trees were bending under the weight of snow. The road bends sharply to the left here.
verb If you bend, you move the upper part of your body downwards or to the side so that it is rounded or at an angle. Bend down and try to pick up the parcel. If you bend this way a bit, you may be able to see him behind the shed.
noun A bend in something is a curved part or a change in its direction. We came suddenly to a sharp bend in the road. There's a bend in the pipe just below the tap.
bend over backwards If someone bends over backwards to do something for you, they try very hard to do it. My mother is always bending over backwards to be helpful to everyone. I've bent over backwards for you, and you're not a bit grateful.
round the bend In informal language, you say someone is round the bend when you think they are mad. Another expression for this is round the twist. Are you really going to drink all that? You must be round the bend!

form.definition: preposition If something is beneath something else, it is directly under it and covered by it. The rake was hidden beneath a carpet of autumn leaves. My workshop is beneath the house.

preposition If something is beneath something else on a wall or on a printed page or in a painting, it is lower than that thing and usually directly under it. The pot plant would look nice beneath the family portrait. There'll be subtitles beneath the picture on the screen.

preposition If you think someone is beneath you, you think they are inferior to you in their rank or their social standing. A lot of people said Crissa was marrying beneath her, because Tony was a labourer.
preposition You say behaviour is beneath you if you believe you shouldn't do it because it does not meet your moral standards or is not appropriate to your social position.
noun A benefactor is someone who helps or gives money to people who need it. Pat could only go to university because a benefactor paid for his education.

adjective You say something is beneficial when it helps to improve some condition or situation. Exercise is very beneficial to your health. A drop in interest rates will be beneficial if you want to buy a house.

dictionary.entry: beneficiarybEn@`fIS@ri:beneficiaries noun A beneficiary is someone who receives benefits or help, especially money left to them in a will. My brother and I are named in our father's will as his beneficiaries.

form.definition: noun A benefit is anything you receive that will help you or improve your life. Being able to speak and write English well has been a great benefit in finding a good job.

noun A benefit is also money given to you by the government or an insurance fund if you are unemployed, sick, or in need of assistance. Are you entitled to medical benefits? You must register with the CES and the Department of Social Security if you want to get unemployment benefits.
noun A benefit is also a concert organised to raise money for a charity. Are you going to the big benefit next week, for the flood victims?
verb If something benefits you, it helps you or is good for you. A nice long hot bath will benefit me greatly. Wage rises won't benefit us if prices keep rising at the same time.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See beneficial.

form.definition: adjective Someone who is benevolent is kind and generous and always wants to help other people. Do you ever donate any money to benevolent organisations like the Red Cross or the Salvation Army? I'm not in a very benevolent mood today.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun benevolence My uncle looked on me with kindly benevolence.adverb benevolently

form.definition: adjective You say someone is benign when they are kind and gentle. She gave the children a benign smile.
adjective You say a tumour is benign when it does not grow or spread to cause serious illness and death. The opposite of this is malignant. The doctor told me the small growth on my arm was benign.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb benignly Their uncle smiled benignly.

form.definition: verb Bent is the past tense and past participle of bend.
adjective If something is bent, it doesn't have its original shape any more and is now curved or crooked. We can't use this fork any more, it's bent.
noun If you have a bent for something, you have an interest in it and a natural ability for it. Riley has a real bent for Japanese music.
bent on If you are bent on doing something, you are determined to do it. He seems bent on going fishing this summer.
verb If you bequeath your money or property to someone, you say in your will that you want them to have it after you die. My aunt bequeathed all her jewellery to me.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bequest The college was established by the bequest of Robert Turner.

form.definition: adjective A bereaved person is someone whose close relative or friend has just died.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bereavement

form.definition: adjective In formal language, if you are bereft of something, you no longer have it or you completely lack it. The fire left them bereft of all their furniture. I was totally bereft of ideas.
noun A beret is a flat round cap, usually made of soft wool. Soldiers and French country people often wear them.

noun A berry is a small round soft fruit with tiny seeds. It grows on a bush or tree. There are many types of berries you can eat, but some are poisonous. Every summer we used to pick lots of berries which Mum would make into delicious jam.

adjective You say someone is berserk or has gone berserk when they have lost control of themselves and have become very angry and violent. In informal language, you often just mean that they are very cross about something. Boyd went berserk and started lashing out with a knife. When my father finds out I've scratched the car he'll go berserk.
noun A berth is a bed on a boat, ship, train or caravan. How many berths does this caravan have? I couldn't get a berth on the train, so I had to sit up all night.
noun A berth is also a space at a dock where a ship can tie up.

give a wide berth If you give a wide berth to someone or something, you stay at a safe distance from them because they are either dangerous or very unpleasant. I'd give that gang of boys on the corner a wide berththey look pretty nasty to me.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis word with birth. ... WORD FAMILY verb berth The ship will berth at Wharf 10 at 7 a.m.

form.definition: preposition If you are beside someone or something, you are close by them. You are next to them. The child stood beside his mother. Put the fork beside your plate.
preposition If you put something beside something else, you compare them. Beside the last job I had, this one is well-paid.
beside the point If you say that something is beside the point, you mean that it isn't usefully related to the matter you are considering.
beside yourself If you are beside yourself, you feel out of control and desperate. Zoe felt beside herself, caught in a traffic jam on the way to the airport.
preposition Besides can mean 'as well as'. Who else is missing besides Jenny?
adverb Besides can introduce another consideration beyond what has already been said. Joan doesn't feel like going out and, besides, it's raining.
verb When an army besieges a town, it surrounds the town and waits for the inhabitants to surrender.
verb If you are besieged by many people, they crowd around you because they want something from you. When you were famous, you were always besieged by fans wanting your autograph.
adjective Best is the superlative form of good.
adverb Best is the superlative form of well.
noun At a wedding ceremony, the best man is the bridegroom's chief helper. You've been a wonderful friend to me all these years. I'd like you to be best man at my wedding next month.

dictionary.entry:
betbEtbetsbet\minion0\\optima0\bettedbetting 1 noun When you make a bet, you promise to give someone something, usually money, if you are wrong and they are right. If you are right and the other person is wrong, they will have to give you money. I made a bet with Ray that I'd beat him at squash. Did you win your bet? I always
verb If you bet on something, you risk money, or something valuable, on the result of a future event. I bet I can jump higher than you. I wouldn't bet on that horse, it's bound to lose.

form.definition: verb If someone betrays you, they are unfaithful or disloyal to you. Don betrayed his wife by having an affair with another woman. During a war, there are always people who betray their country by helping the enemy.
verb If you betray something, you show or reveal it when you shouldn't. His trembling voice and shaking hands betrayed his nervousness. Vinotha never betrayed my secret.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun betrayal His wife was deeply hurt by his betrayal.

form.definition: adjective Better is the comparative form of good.
adverb Better is the comparative form of well.
preposition Between refers to the space, time or amount which separates things. He'll see you between two and four. There's a fence between the two gardens.
preposition If something happens between people or countries, it involves all parties. There's a new economic agreement between Asian countries.
preposition If people do something between them, they share the effort or action. Between us we'll soon finish the job.
between you and me If you say to someone between you and me, you want your words to them to go no further. You want them to keep your secret.

noun A beverage is a drink of any kind. This is a rather formal word. You will see it mainly on menus and in signs. We offer a variety of alcoholic beverages. Hot and cold beverages are available in the bar.[qr

dictionary.entry:
bewareb@`wE@, bi:-
verb If a sign or person tells you to beware of something, they are telling you to be very careful and to watch out for danger. If you go to the shops, beware of the traffic!

form.definition: adjective If you are bewildered by something, it confuses or puzzles you. I'm bewildered by all this new computer technology. He was looking about him with a bewildered expression.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is perplexed. ... WORD FAMILY verb bewilder English spelling often bewilders me.adjective bewildering This picture is bewildering. I just can't work out what it's meant to be.noun bewilderment To my bewilderment, he then left and the first man came in again.

form.definition: verb If someone or something bewitches you, you are very charmed by what they do or how they look. Dame Joan Sutherland bewitched thousands of opera lovers with her singing.
verb In a fairytale, if you have been bewitched by someone, they have cast a magic spell on you.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective bewitching You're looking very bewitching tonight, my dear.

form.definition: preposition If something is beyond a certain point, it is further than it. The creek is beyond the back paddock.
preposition If something is beyond you, it is too much for you to understand. How you keep working in those conditions is beyond me.
adjective A biannual event takes place twice a year. Biannual visits to the dentist are advised.
form.note: ... COMPAREthis with biennial. ... WORD FAMILY adverb biannually New students are admitted biannually.

form.definition: noun If you have a bias, you hold a strong opinion which stops you from seeing or understanding someone else's point of view. Many people have a bias against other ethnic groups. My wife likes cats, but I have a bias in favour of dogs.
verb If you are biased by someone or something, you have let them influence you and form your opinion for you, often in a bad way. Don't let his arguments bias you against the real facts.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective biased The report was heavily biased.

form.definition: noun A bib is a cloth you tie under a small child's chin to make sure its clothes won't get dirty when it eats.
noun A bib is also the upper part of an apron or overalls which covers your chest.
noun The Bible is the sacred book upon which the Christian and Jewish religions are based.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective biblical Do you believe the biblical account of creation?

form.definition: noun A bibliography is a list of all the books and articles you used when writing a book or an essay.
noun A bicentenary is a 200th anniversary. The bicentenary of the first European settlement in Australia was in 1988.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective bicentennial

form.definition: adjective A bicentennial celebration is one that happens every 200 years. The bicentennial celebrations lasted all week.
noun Your biceps is the large muscle in the top part of your arm.
verb If people bicker, they argue about small unimportant things. The kids were bickering over who should do the washing-up.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bickering Stop that bickering!

form.definition: noun A bicycle is a two-wheeled vehicle which you ride by pushing two pedals with your feet.
form.note: ... OTHER WORDSfor this are bike, pushbike and cycle.

dictionary.entry:
bidbIdformeaning1\optima0\bidsbidbidden, bidding; verb forms for meanings 2 & 3 bidsbadebiddenbidding
verb If you bid for something that is being sold at an auction, you offer to pay a particular price for it. Luis bid $3,000 for the 1985 Holden sedan.
verb In rather formal language, if you bid someone good morning or farewell, you say hello or goodbye to them. Our boss never so much as bids us good morning. Lots of Rosa's friends came to the airport to bid her farewell.
verb In rather formal or literary language, if you bid someone to do something, you ask or command them to do it. The court official bade the accused woman to sit in the dock.
noun A bid is an attempt to do or obtain something. The prisoners made a bid for freedom by trying to dig a tunnel under the wall.
