noun A bid is the amount that you offer to pay at an auction. Why don't you put in a bid for that car? None of the bids matched the reserve price.
noun A bid is also an offer to do a job for a particular price. The big Japanese company put in a bid to build the tunnel.
... WORD FAMILY noun bidding The bidding quickly reached $300,000.

form.definition: verb If you bide your time, you wait for just the right moment to do something. Don't ask for your promotion yet. Bide your time till the boss is in a better mood.
adjective A biennial event takes place once every two years. Compare this with biannual.
noun A biennial is a plant that lives for two years, or produces seeds in its second year.[qr

dictionary.entry:
bifocalsba:I`f@Uk@lz
noun Bifocals are eye glasses with lenses which are made up of two parts. The upper part is made for looking at things far away, and the bottom part is made for close reading.
... WORD FAMILY adjective bifocal ...bifocal lenses.

form.definition: adjective Something that is big is large in size or amount. Australia is a big country. If you misbehave, you'll be in big trouble! He's earning a big salary. 2 adjective You can say something is big when it's very important. What are the big issues of the day? One day I'll be a big film star.
adjective You say you have a big brother or sister when you have a brother or sister who is older than you. My big sister is a doctor.
noun Bigamy is the crime of marrying someone while you're still married to someone else.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bigamist adjective bigamous The marriage was bigamous, as his first wife was still alive.

form.definition: noun In informal language, if you say something is a biggie, you mean it's large or important. I think Sunday's peace march is going to be a biggie.
noun A bight is a bend or curve in the coastline. It is larger than a bay, and curves less.

noun A bigot is someone who has very strong and biased opinions. Such people don't like to listen to other opinions, and often get very angry when someone else disagrees with them, especially about matters of race, religion or politics.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective bigoted noun bigotry Bigotry and racism are often the result of lack of education.

form.definition: noun Bike is an informal word for bicycle or motorcycle. Li-Ling wants a new bike for Christmas.
noun A bikini is a two-piece swimming suit for women.
noun Bile is the yellowish bitter-tasting liquid made by your liver which helps you to digest fat.
noun Bile is also used, in rather formal language, to refer to a display of bad temper or resentment. She was in a foul temper, and we had to suffer her bile and anger for ages.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See bilious.

form.definition: adjective Someone who is bilingual can speak two languages fluently. Many migrants in Australia are bilingual.
adjective Something that is bilingual is written in or spoken in two languages. Canada is a bilingual country. ...a bilingual dictionary.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bilingual Jan was born in Holland and is a bilingual.

form.definition: adjective You say something, especially a colour or a pattern, is bilious if you think it's disgusting or unpleasant. She wore a dress of bilious green.
adjective In rather formal language, you say someone is bilious if they are angry or bad-tempered. My father was in a bilious mood last week.
adjective If you feel bilious, you feel sick in the stomach because you've got too much bile in your body. He often gets these bilious attacks.
noun A bill is a written statement telling you how much money you owe someone for goods or services. I asked the waiter if I could have the bill. The bill for his operation came to over $4000.
noun A bill is also a written plan for a new law which is presented in Parliament for discussion and consideration. There was a very heated debate over the bill to introduce national identity cards.
noun A bill is also a printed notice you stick on walls or electricity poles. POST NO BILLS
noun The bill of a show or concert is the people and items that will appear in it. Which bands are on the bill at the pub tonight? ... a double bill of two one-act plays.
noun A bill is also the beak of a bird.

bill of health A bill of health is a report about the health of a person or the condition of a machine. I went to the doctor for a check-up and she gave me a clean bill of health. The engineers gave the ship a perfect bill of health before it left port.
bill of rights A bill of rights is an official document listing all the legal things the citizens of a country are allowed to do.
bill of sale A bill of sale is an official written document which tells you something has been sold by one person to another.
fit the bill You say something fits the bill when it is exactly what you want or need. I'm tired and fed up. A nice holiday in the Snowy Mountains would fit the bill beautifully.

foot the bill If you foot the bill for something, you pay for it. Naomi smashed her car but couldn't pay for the damage, so her father had to foot the bill. 11 top the bill If you say someone tops the bill, they are the main performer in a play or concert. ... WORD FAMILY verb bill The hospital billed me over $10 000 for my operation. Pavarotti is billed to sing at the Sydney Opera House next month.
noun A billabong is a large pond. Billabongs are formed when rivers change their course and leave the body of water behind.
noun A billboard is a large board on which you can stick advertising posters or bills.
noun A billet is a house where soldiers or members of a team can stay for a while. The scout troop from Western Australia were given billets in our street.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb billet We were asked if we could billet a soldier for a few days.noun billet We've got two billets from Argentina staying with us next week.

form.definition: noun Billiards is a game that two or more people play on a large table. You use a long stick (called a cue) to hit different coloured balls against each other and into pockets around the edge of the table. Let's go to the pub for a few beers and a couple of games of billiards.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective billiard ...a billiard ball. ...a billiard table.

form.definition: noun A billion is a thousand million (1|000|000|000).
noun In informal language, you can also use billion to mean a very large number of items. There were billions of birds nesting on that island. She's always got a billion excuses.
noun A billow is a very large wave.
verb When a sail or flag billows in the wind, it fills out with air and waves around. The sails billowed in the strong breeze.
verb When things like smoke or clouds billow, they form large swirling masses. Her dress billowed behind her as she came down the stairs.
noun A billy is a tin container with a handle and lid. You use it on an open fire to boil water. Nothing tastes better than a cup of tea made in a billy.
noun A bin is a container in which you store things. Our garbage bin is emptied twice a week. ...a bread bin.

dictionary.entry:
bindba:Indbindsboundbinding 1 verb If you bind things together, you tie them up with something such as string or rope so that they are held tightly together. Bind those papers together before you move them. The flowers were
verb If you bind something, you tie it up firmly. That's a bad cut. You'll need to bind it up with a bandage. Jenny's hair was bound with a long black ribbon.
verb If you bind substances together, you mix them so that they will stick together in a mass. You need an egg to bind the ingredients.
verb When you bind a book, you fasten its pages together and put a cover around them. This old book is falling apartwe'll have to get it bound again.
verb If you are bound by an agreement or contract, you are under a legal obligation to keep to its conditions. With this special contract, the company is bound to pay all your medical expenses if you get sick.
noun You say a situation is a bind when it's annoying and unpleasant, but you can't do much about it. Having to wash and cook for a large family must be a real bind.
... WORD FAMILY noun binder Put those pages in your loose leaf binder.noun binding The binding came undone and the papers fell on the floor.adjective binding This agreement is binding.

form.definition: noun A bindi-eye is a small spiky seed from a weed that grows in many peoples' lawns. Don't walk on the lawn with bare feetthere are lots of bindi-eyes in it.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is bindy.

form.definition: noun Bingo is a game where you have a card with a lot of numbers on it which you cross out as someone calls them. If you are the first person to have all your numbers called out, you are the winner. You can win money or prizes. Let's go to the local community hall; they've got bingo on tonight.
form.note: ... OTHER WORDSfor this are lotto or housie.

form.definition: noun A pair of binoculars is a pair of short telescopes joined together which you look through to see things in the distance more clearly. Take a pair of binoculars with you to the concert because you might be sitting a long way from the stage.
adjective A biodegradable chemical or substance is one that can be broken down into environmentally harmless products. This is done by the sun or bacteria. ...biodegradable soap powder.

dictionary.entry: biographyba:I`Ogr@fi:biographies noun A biography is the story of a person's life which is written by someone else. Have you read the biography of Bob Hawke? ... COMPAREthis with autobiography. ... WORD FAMILY adjective biographical I've found some interesting biographical information about Captain Cook.

form.definition: noun A biologist is a person who studies the science of all living things.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun biology My cousin is studying biology at university.adjective biological Rainforests have great biological diversity.

form.definition: noun If you have a biopsy done, a few cells are removed from your body and tested to see if they are diseased or infected. The doctor didn't know if the lump on my arm was benign or malignant, so he suggested I have a biopsy.
noun A bird is a creature with feathers and wings. Most birds can fly, and female birds lay eggs.
noun In informal language, you can call a person a bird, especially when you're talking about someone who's a bit strange. He's a funny old bird, isn't he?
noun Bird is also an informal word for a young woman. Many women find this use of the word offensive. Who was that bird I saw you with on the weekend?
noun Biro is another word for ballpoint.
noun Your birth is the occasion on which you were born. Sue's expecting the birth of her first child. What is your date of birth? Kangaroos weigh only a few grams at birth.
noun A birth is also the beginning or origin of something. Last year saw the birth of a new venture for us. Such concepts date back to the birth of computer technology.

noun Your birthday is the annual anniversary of the day you were born. In Australia, you often give people cards and presents on their birthday, and they may have a party. My birthday's on 23 January. When's yours? Happy birthday!
noun A biscuit is a small flat cake that has been baked until it is crisp. Would you like a biscuit with your tea? ...biscuits and cheese.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this, in informal language, is bikkie.

form.definition: verb In formal or technical language, if you bisect something, you divide it into two equal parts. Use a pair of compasses to bisect the line.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis with dissect, which means to cut up the body of a plant or animal to see what it's made of or how it works. ... WORD FAMILY noun bisection

form.definition: adjective A plant or animal is bisexual if it has both male and female sex organs.
adjective You say someone is bisexual if they are sexually attracted to both males and females.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bisexuality He kept his bisexuality a secret.

form.definition: noun A bishop is a priest who has a high rank in the Christian church and is in charge of a large district.
noun A bishop is also a piece on a chess board that you can move diagonally any number of squares.
noun A bistro is a small restaurant or bar.
noun A bit is a small piece or amount of something. I need a bit of paper to write on. Watch out, there are bits of glass all over the floor!
noun A bit is also a short period of time. Do you mind waiting for a bit? I'm just going out for a bit.
noun A bit is also a metal bar attached to a pair of reins which you put in a horse's mouth. You use it to help steer and control the horse.
noun A bit is also the sharp part of a tool you use for cutting or drilling holes. This drill bit is blunt; we'll have to sharpen it.
noun A bit is also the smallest unit of information a computer can keep in its memory. Eight bits makes a byte.
a bit much You say something is a bit much if it's unfair or more than you can accept. I think it's a bit much that we're expected to put up with all this noise.
do your bit If someone asks you to do your bit, they're asking you to do your share of the work that needs to be done. It's about time you did your bit. I try to do my bit around the house.
not a bit You use not a bit when you want to make a strong positive statement. 'Do you mind waiting?' 'No, not a bit!' Janine, you haven't changed a bit. Mark was not a bit like his father.
quite a bit Quite a bit means 'a lot'. He'd had quite a bit to drink. Pedro earns quite a bit of money.

to bits If you take, smash or blow something to bits, it comes apart or is broken into many small pieces. He took the motor to bits, then tried to fix it. He threw the glass onto the floor and it smashed to bits.
noun In informal language, bitch is also an offensive word for a nasty and bad-tempered woman.
verb In informal language, if you say someone bitches all the time, you mean they complain continually. I wish you'd stop bitching about the weather.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bitchiness adjective bitchy (bitchier, bitchiest) I wish she'd stop that bitchy behaviour.

dictionary.entry:
biteba:Itbitesbitbittenbiting 1 verb When you bite something, you use your teeth to cut, grab or take a piece out of it. The dog bit me on the leg. Watch out, that dog bites! I can't bite properly with these false teeth. She bit hungrily
verb When an insect or snake bites you, it pierces your skin and injects poison into you. Inge was bitten on the toe by a bull ant. Where's the insect repellent? The mosquitoes are biting tonight.
verb If you're fishing and the fish are biting, they are eating the bait on your hook. The fish are really biting tonight.
noun If you have a bite to eat, you have a snack or something to eat. I'm hungry. Let's go to the hamburger shop for a bite to eat.
noun A bite is the wound which you get on your skin when an animal bites you. The baby was covered with mosquito bites. George was bleeding from the dog bite.

form.definition: adjective You say something tastes bitter when it has a sharp, unpleasant biting taste. Strong black coffee without sugar tastes quite bitter.
adjective When the weather is bitter, it is very cold. Put on a warm coatthere's a bitter wind blowing outside. Penguins don't seem to feel the bitter cold.

adjective If you have a bitter experience, you find it very hard to accept or bear that experience. It took me a long time to get over the bitter blow of her death. He's still very bitter about his dismissal.
adjective You say a war, fight or argument is bitter when it's very fierce and full of anger and hate. The war has been very bitter. They've been bitter enemies for years. It was a bitter divorce.

the bitter end If you do something to the bitter end, you keep on doing it until it's finished, even though it's very unpleasant. In informal language, you can use the bitter end to emphasise that you mean the very end of something. The rebels swore they'd fight till the bitter end. I stayed at the party to the bitter end.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bitterness I like a beer with a touch of bitterness.bitterly It's bitterly cold today. Navaz wept bitterly.

form.definition: noun Bitumen is a sticky black mixture, like tar or asphalt, which is used to make roads.
noun You can refer to a tarred road as the bitumen. I can't wait to take this new bike onto the bitumen.
verb When you bivouac, you set up camp for the night and, usually, sleep without tents. The soldiers bivouacked in the bush for ten days as part of their training.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bivouac The scout troop went on a bivouac.

form.definition: adjective You say something is bizarre if it's very odd or unusual. The doctors were very worried by Minh's bizarre behaviour. That's one of the most bizarre outfits I've ever seen!

dictionary.entry:
blabblAbblabsblabbedblabbing 1 verb In informal language, if you say someone blabs, you mean they talk too much. I don't get to say much when my sister phones meshe just
verb In informal language, if you blab something, you tell or reveal it, even though you are not supposed to. Josie got confused and ended up blabbing the whole plan.[xp\start\[ap--black 1 adjective If something is black, it is completely dark and has no colour or brightness. It is the same colour as coal or charcoal. The opposite of this is white. The sky was completely black, as it seldom is in Europe. She's got black hair. The cloth was black with dirt. Please complete the form in black ink.
blAkblackerblackest
adjective You say a situation is black when it's very bad or hopeless. The future of the economy looks very black at the moment. Things were pretty black for me that Christmas.
adjective Someone who is black belongs to a race which has dark-coloured skin.
adjective If you say you want your coffee or tea black, you mean that you want it without milk or cream. The opposite of this is white coffee or tea, which has milk added to it. I'll have a black coffee with two sugars, please.
... WORD FAMILY noun black We all wore black to the funeral. It's written there in black and white. South African blacks got the vote in 1994.verb blacken

form.definition: noun A blackboard is a large smooth board, painted black or dark green, which hangs at the front of a classroom. Teachers use it to write or draw on with chalk.
noun A blackhead is a small pimple with a black tip that you get on your skin, usually on your face.

verb If someone tries to blackmail you, they want you to give them money or do something for them. If you don't, they will reveal secrets about you. The minister was blackmailed for years by a former mistress who threatened to reveal his affair to the press.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun blackmail I won't give in to blackmail.noun blackmailer The blackmailer was jailed for five years.

form.definition: noun A blackout is an electrical power failure. There was a blackout during the storm and we had to re-set our digital clock.
noun If you have a blackout, you lose consciousness for a short time. Carolyn suffers from blackouts which the doctors can't explain.

noun Someone is called the black sheep of a family when people think they are not as good or successful as the rest of the family. Bob's the black sheep in their family. He's never shown any interest in finding a proper job.
noun A blacksmith is someone who makes things out of iron, such as horseshoes.
noun Your bladder is the organ inside your body which stores urine.
noun A bladder is also a bag made of rubber which gets bigger when you fill it with air or liquid. You can't pump up the football until you patch the hole in the bladder.
noun A blade is the flat cutting part of a knife, sword or axe. This knife is bluntyou'll have to sharpen the blade.
noun A blade of grass is a single leaf of it.
noun A blade of an object is the thin, flat part, like the flat end of an oar that goes into the water.
verb When you blame a person or thing for something bad that happens, you say it is their fault. He blamed the traffic for making him late. Don't blame meit's not my fault if it doesn't work.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun blame He laid the blame on Gita. I accept some of the blame for the delay.

form.definition: adjective You say food tastes bland if it has little flavour or spice. I'll never go to that restaurant againthe food is so bland and boring. I'm on a bland diet because of my stomach ulcer.

adjective You say someone or something is bland if they seem polite and reasonable, but there is not much excitement or feeling in them. The news report of the incident was very bland. He gave a bland smile.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb blandly He smiled blandly.noun blandness

dictionary.entry:
blankblANkblankerblankest 1 adjective You say something is blank when there is nothing written or printed on it. All of a sudden the computer screen went blank. Has anyone got
adjective If someone has a blank look on their face, they show no understanding, feeling or interest. After the accident, Robert just stood there with a blank expression on his face.
adjective If your mind goes blank, you suddenly can't remember something you need to remember. I tried to remember his name, but my mind went completely blank.
noun A blank is an empty space on a form which you have to fill in. Please complete all the blanks or write 'not applicable'. 5 blank cheque A blank cheque is a cheque on which the amount that has to be paid has not been filled in. We also use it to mean an unlimited promise of support, especially financial support. They were so impressed with our research they basically wrote us a blank cheque to pursue it.
draw a blank In informal language, if you say you draw a blank when you are trying to do something, it means that you are unsuccessful. The police realised that they'd drawn a blank in following up what they thought was a major clue to the murder.
... WORD FAMILY adverb blankly She stared at me blanklyshe'd obviously forgotten who I was.

form.definition: noun A blanket is a large rectangular or square piece of cloth, usually wool or cotton, which you put on a bed over the sheets to keep you warm.
noun A blanket is also a thick layer or covering of anything. We woke in the morning to find the whole valley covered in a blanket of snow.

adjective You use blanket to describe something which covers all aspects or possibilities. We think there should be a blanket ban on smoking in restaurants. 'Equipment' is a blanket term for various machines and tools.

wet blanket You call someone a wet blanket if they never join in fun that everyone else is having, or if they try to stop other people from having fun. Don't be such a wet blanketit won't do any harm. As usual Joan was a wet blanket and wanted to leave early.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb blanket Fog blanketed the town.

form.definition: verb When a car horn, radio or something similar blares, it makes a very loud and harsh sound. The ambulance raced to the hospital with its siren blaring.
verb If you blaspheme, you speak about God or other sacred things without respect.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective blasphemous noun blasphemy

form.definition: noun A blast is a sudden and very strong gust of wind or air. There was a blast of icy wind when he opened the door.
noun A blast is also the sudden loud sound made by a whistle or horn. The other driver gave a few blasts of his horn to express his impatience.
noun A blast is also an explosion.
verb If you blast something, you destroy or break it up with bombs or explosives. The construction team blasted a tunnel through the mountain.
verb If you blast somebody, you criticise them severely. My boss really blasted me for losing the contract. Local politicians love to blast the federal government.
interjection People sometimes use blast to show, in a very informal way, that they are annoyed about something. Blast! It's raining again. Blast this stupid car!
noun In informal language, if you say something you do is a blast, you mean it is really enjoyable. The party was a real blast.
blast off When a rocket or spacecraft blasts off, it takes off from the ground to begin its journey into space.

full blast If music is being played full blast, it's very loud. My neighbour always plays her stereo full blast. He turned on the TV full blast while I was trying to sleep. By midnight the live band was going full blast.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun blast-off

form.definition: adjective You say that something bad is blatant when it's very easy to see or it is obvious. There is no attempt to conceal or disguise it. That's a blatant lie! We both know that I paid my share. ...a blatant attempt at bribery. Their threats were quite blatant.
noun A blaze is something burning, for example a bushfire or a bonfire. Firefighters fought to control the huge blaze in the factory. Use plenty of dry leaves to get the blaze going.
noun A blaze is a bright light. The blaze of the blowtorch lit up the cellar. I was dazzled by a blaze of flashbulbs.
verb When something blazes with light or colour, it is very bright and colourful. I woke up with the sun blazing through my window. In spring our garden blazes with colour.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See ablaze.

form.definition: noun A blazer is a jacket, often with a badge or emblem sewn on the breast pocket. It is usually worn by members of a sports club or by school pupils as part of their school uniform.

verb If you bleach something, you make it paler or remove a stain, either by using a chemical or by leaving it in the sun. Many teenagers like to wear bleached jeans. Her hair was bleached by the sun. You should be able to bleach that mark out.

noun Bleach is a chemical you use to bleach fabric or clothing. You also use it to kill germs, for example in a lavatory bowl, and to clean mould off walls. Don't put too much bleach in the washing machine or you'll ruin the sheets.
adjective If a place is bleak, it is unattractive and bare. The moon looks a pretty bleak place to me. They live on one of those bleak new housing estates.

adjective You say a situation is bleak when it is depressing and there is little hope of improvement. With no qualifications my employment prospects were bleak. With a cancer of this type the outlook is bleak.
adjective You say the weather is bleak if it is cloudy and cold. The weather's too bleak to go sailing this afternoon.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bleakness adverb bleakly He stared bleakly out of the window.

dictionary.entry: bleary`blI@ri:blearierbleariest adjective If your eyes are bleary, they are itchy and watery because you are very tired. His eyes were bleary and he looked exhausted after being awake all night. ... WORD FAMILY adverb blearily He looked blearily around him.

form.definition: noun A bleat is the sound that a sheep, goat or calf makes.

verb When somebody bleats about something, they complain about it. If you use this word, you mean that their complaining annoys you. I'm sick of hearing you bleat about your problemswhy don't you think of other people for a change?

dictionary.entry:
bleedbli:dbleedsbledbleeding 1 verb When you bleed, you lose blood from your body because of an injury or illness. Her arm's bleeding badlywe'll have to bandage it with
verb If you bleed something, you withdraw liquid or blood from it. I'll have to bleed the brakes of the car at the weekend. You use this key to bleed air out of the radiators. 3 verb If someone bleeds you of money, they take a great deal of money away from you. He won the old lady's confidence and bled her of every cent she owned.

form.definition: noun When something has a blemish, it has a mark or imperfection which spoils its appearance. These shoes are reduced because of a slight blemish in the leather. This face cream will conceal spots and blemishes.
verb If something blemishes your reputation, it spoils or damages it. Revelation of the affair has done little to blemish his public image.
verb When you blend substances, you mix them together smoothly. To make concrete you must blend cement, sand, stones and water. Blend the ingredients into a stiff paste.

verb When several things blend together, they combine to make a pleasing effect. None of them is dominant or out of place. The piano and flute blend well with each other. We should try to build houses that blend with their surroundings.

blend into When something blends into the background, it looks or sounds so much like its surroundings that you can hardly see or hear it. Some insects have camouflage markings that let them blend into their habitat.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See blender. noun blend ...a delicious blend of fruit juices.

form.definition: noun A blender is an electrical appliance you use in the kitchen to chop and mix food. You can make soup very easily if you've got a blender.
verb When a priest blesses someone, he or she asks God to protect them. The bishop blessed the congregation.
verb When a priest blesses something, he or she makes it sacred. The Pope blessed the new cathedral.
blessed with If people say you are blessed with a particular skill or good quality, they mean you are very lucky to have it. Greg is blessed with a lot of good sense.
bless you (a) People often say bless you as a response when someone sneezes. The person who has sneezed then usually says 'thank you'.
(b) Some people also say bless you to thank you for being helpful or for doing something nice. You'll do the shopping? Bless you, that's a great help.
noun A blessing is a gift from God or anything that you receive that brings you a lot of happiness. After three years of drought, the rain was a great blessing.

noun If you have someone's blessing, you have their approval or support for something you want to do. Mick and Rosa were married with their parents' blessing. If you want to go ahead with that plan, you'll certainly have my blessing. I can't give my blessing to such a risky venture.

mixed blessing You say something is a mixed blessing when it has some advantages, but also disadvantages. Having twins is a mixed blessingthere's double the joy, but also double the work for the parents.
verb Blew is the past tense of blow.
noun Blight is a disease plants get which causes the infected parts to dry up and die.
noun A blight is anything which causes damage or unhappiness. His father's death just before his marriage put a blight on Leon's happiness.
adjective You say someone is blind when they can't see because their eyes are not working. He was blind from birth.
adjective You say someone is blind to a situation when they can't or won't take notice of it. His parents seemed blind to his drug problem.
noun A blind is a covering in front of a window to help keep the sun out, or to stop people from looking inside.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb blind The fierce light of the sun blinded him for a few minutes.noun blindness

form.definition: verb If you blindfold someone, you tie a piece of cloth over their eyes so that they cannot see.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun blindfold ...a blindfold over my eyes.

form.definition: verb When you blink, you quickly close your eyelids and open them again. The camera flash made us blink. They emerged blinking into the strong lights.
verb When a light blinks, it flashes on and off.
on the blink In informal language, when you say a machine or apparatus is on the blink, you mean it isn't working properly. The photocopier's on the blink again.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See blinker.

form.definition: noun The blinkers on your car are the lights at the front and back which you turn on to indicate to other drivers that you are going to turn right or left. Another word for this is indicator.

noun Bliss is a feeling of great happiness, joy and delight. Suddenly I felt a great sense of bliss. Fishing in the Snowy Mountains is my idea of bliss. It was bliss to spend a weekend without the kids. ... WORD FAMILY adjective blissful The cool water was blissful.adverb blissfully They were blissfully unaware of the fighting outside.
noun A blister is a small painful swelling on your skin which is filled with clear liquid. My hands were covered with blisters after chopping the firewood. Those new shoes gave me blisters.
noun A blister is also a small bubble or lump that you sometimes see in a painted surface. This is caused by air, water or rust under the paint.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb blister The sun can make your skin blister.

form.definition: adjective You say the weather or sun is blistering when it's extremely hot. It was good to get out of the blistering sun and into the cool.
adjective You say a verbal attack is blistering when it's full of strong feeling and anger. The Treasurer made a blistering attack on his critics.
noun A blitz is a sudden and very heavy attack, especially by war planes.
noun A blitz is also a short period in which something is done intensively. During holiday weekends the police often have a blitz on speeding and drink-driving.
noun A blizzard is a heavy snow storm with very strong winds.

adjective You say something is bloated when it's swollen because it has too much liquid or gas in it. Three weeks after he disappeared, his bloated corpse was found in the river. I always feel bloated after Christmas dinner.
noun A bloc is a group of countries who cooperate with each other because they have the same political or economic ideals.
noun A block is a rectangular or square-shaped piece of solid material. ...a child's building block. ...a block of chocolate.
noun A block is also a piece of land you build a house on. It's supposed to be every Australian's dream to have a house on a quarter-acre block.

noun A block is also a rectangular area of land with houses or buildings on it and surrounded by streets on all four sides. Joe takes the dog for a walk around the block every evening. The post office is just a couple of blocks away from here.

noun A block is also a large building which is divided into flats or offices. You can't keep a dog if you live in a block of flats. I live on the top floor of the block. 5a verb If you block something like a pipe, road or channel, you stop things from moving through it because you have placed something in front, inside or across it. The drain was blocked with leaves. The police blocked the road to stop the traffic.
verb If you block a plan or arrangement, you do something which stops it from succeeding or going ahead. The Senate blocked the proposed bill.
block out (a) If you block out something from your mind, you try not to think about it. You must block everything else out and just concentrate on winning.
(b) Something that blocks out light stops it from reaching you. I pulled down the blind to block out the blazing sun.
lose your block If someone loses their block, they explode with great anger. Dad will lose his block when he finds out you've smashed the car.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective blocked ...a blocked drain.noun blockage The bath wouldn't empty because there was a blockage in the pipe.noun See blockade.

form.definition: verb When an army or navy blockades a city or country, it stops people and goods from entering or leaving.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun blockade

form.definition: noun You call a film or book a blockbuster if it's been very popular and successful.
noun Bloke is an informal word for a man. Dave's a terrific bloke for giving me this job. Come on, you blokes, finish your drinksit's closing time.
adjective Something is blond if it has a light yellowish-brown colour. Anita has curly blond hair. Our house is on the cornerthe one with the blond bricks.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See blonde.

form.definition: noun A blonde is a woman or girl with light-coloured hair.
noun Blood is the red fluid that flows through the veins and arteries of your body.

bad blood If you say there is bad blood between two people, you mean there is a deep hatred or anger between them. There's so much bad blood between the Palestinians and the Israelis that you wonder if there can ever be real peace.
in cold blood If someone does something violent or cruel in cold blood, they do it calmly and apparently without feeling.

in your blood You say something is in your blood if you have a particular talent or quality that is part of your nature and it is shared with other members of your family or culture. It's in my blood to be punctual and reliableit's the German side of me.
make your blood boil When something makes your blood boil, it upsets you so much that you become very angry. Watching the way he treated the animals really made my blood boil.

make your blood run cold If something makes your blood run cold, it makes you absolutely terrified. My blood ran cold when I saw the huge shark in the water. blood when you need someone with different talents or good ideas to improve the way things are done.
noun A bloodbath is when many people are killed very violently. The United Nations can do little to prevent another bloodbath in Africa.
noun Bloodshed is the violent killing and wounding of people. It's time the two sides started talkingthere's been too much bloodshed.
adjective Eyes are said to be bloodshot when the white parts are red and sore. His eyes were bloodshothe hadn't slept for nearly three days.
noun Your bloodstream is your blood as it flows around your body. The drug is injected into the bloodstream.
adjective You say someone is bloodthirsty when they take a lot of pleasure in killing or violence. Idi Amin was the bloodthirsty tyrant of Uganda.
adjective You say a film or book is bloodthirsty if it depicts a lot of violence and killing. The Rambo movies are extremely bloodthirsty.
adjective If something is bloody, it is stained or covered with blood. A pile of bloody bandages lay in the corner. His hand was crushed to a bloody pulp.
adjective You say a fight or battle is bloody if it causes the loss of many lives. World War I was the bloodiest war the world has seen.

adverb In informal language, if someone says that something is bloody good, they mean it is very good. If they say something is bloody awful, they mean it is very bad. The word is used for emphasis but its use offends some people.
adjective You say someone is being bloody-minded when they are making difficulties for everyone by refusing to cooperate. Stop being so bloody-minded, and come and give us a hand!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bloody-mindedness

form.definition: verb When a plant or tree blooms, it produces flowers.
verb When someone or something blooms, they are in a healthy or growing state. The kids are blooming in the wonderful climate. When they met again by chance their relationship bloomed.
in bloom You say a plant or tree is in bloom when it has flowers.
noun Blossoms are the flowers of a fruit tree. There is nothing prettier than apple blossoms in spring time. The bride's veil was trimmed with orange blossom.
verb When someone or something blossoms, it develops and grows in a pleasing way. She blossomed into a wonderful musician. Our friendship blossomed over the years.
in blossom You say a tree or plant is in blossom when it has flowers.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb blossom The apple trees are blossoming.

form.definition: noun A blot is something, especially ink, which has been spilled onto a page or some other surface to form a stain.
noun If you have a blot on your reputation, you have done something bad which makes people think less well of you. His conviction for drink-driving will be a major blot on his reputation.
verb When you blot a surface, you remove liquid from it using something absorbent such as a paper towel or a piece of cloth. Blot the surface dry without rubbing.

blot out (a) If you blot out something from your memory, you deliberately forget all about it. I was determined to blot out the past and look to the future. Many victims blot out memories of the abuse.
(b) If one thing blots out another, it is in the way so that the other thing cannot be seen or heard. The dark clouds blotted out the warm sun.
noun A blouse is a loose-fitting shirt worn by women and girls.
verb When the wind blows, the air moves. There's quite a gale blowing. Can you hear the wind blowing through the trees?

verb If the wind or a fan blows something somewhere, the thing is moved there by the force of the air moving. The fan blew all his papers onto the floor. The wind keeps blowing my hat off. The fence was blown down during the night.

verb When you blow, you send out a stream of air from your mouth. The police officer asked him to blow into the breathalyser. I blew onto my fingers to keep them warm. Blow hard, and try to put all the candles out.
verb If you blow a whistle, horn or other musical instrument, you make a sound come out of it by blowing into it. The referee blew the whistle to mark the end of the match.
verb When you blow your nose, you clear it by breathing hard through it and into a handkerchief.
verb When an electrical fuse or a light bulb blows, it stops working because a part of it has burned or melted. We must have too many lights on that circuitthe fuse keeps blowing.

verb In informal language, if you say that you blow your money, you mean that you spend it extravagantly and waste it. She blew her lottery win on new clothes and jewellery. He blew $3000 in two weeks.

verb When you blow a chance or opportunity, you lose it because you make a wrong decision. Don't blow your chances by not dressing neatly for the interview. Angelo blew the exam because he didn't read the instructions properly.
noun A blow is the action of hitting someone or something with your hand or with something held in it. The victim received several blows to the back of the head with a heavy instrument.

noun A blow is also a disappointment that you experience. Something happens to you that causes you great shock and dismay or upsets your plans. Her father's death was a tremendous blow to her. The rise in oil prices has dealt a blow to the economy's chances of recovery.
blow in If someone blows in, they arrive unexpectedly. Guess who blew in this morning?
blow out (a) When you blow out a candle, you blow at it so that it stops burning.

(b) If a tyre on your car blows out, it bursts suddenly. 13 blow over If something such as an argument or a scandal blows over, it is forgotten because it is no longer important. The kids are always squabbling, but it all blows over in minutes. He kept a low profile until the media interest blew over. 14 blow up (a) If you blow something up or something blows up, there is an explosion which destroys it. They threatened to blow up the plane. The building could blow up at any minute. The bomb blew up in his face.
(b) You say a storm or an argument is blowing up when you can see the early signs of it. We'd better take in the washing, there's quite a storm blowing up. A big row is blowing up over the Budget.
(c) When you blow up a balloon or tyre, you fill it with air.
noun A blowout is a sudden bursting of the tyre of a car. The accident was caused by a blowout at high speed.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb See blow (definition 12b).

form.definition: noun A blowtorch is a tool that produces an extremely hot flame. You use it for welding or cutting metal, or for stripping paint from a surface.
noun Blubber is the fat from sea mammals, especially whales. It is used to make oil.
noun You can also use blubber to refer, in an offensive way, to the fat on a person's body. If you took some exercise you might get rid of some of that blubber.
verb When someone blubbers, they cry noisily. If you use this word you mean that you are not sorry for them. Stop blubbering like a spoiled baby!
verb If you bludge, you avoid working when you should be. It makes me mad the way some of us do all the work and others just bludge.
verb If you bludge something from someone, you get them to give it to you. Can I bludge a cigarette from you? The girls regularly bludge $10 from me at the weekend.

verb When someone bludges on you, they take unfair advantage of you by taking or using things that you own, without any intention of repaying you. It's time you got a job and stopped bludging on your parents at your age. ... WORD FAMILY noun bludge Working in this place is a good bludge.noun bludger The politician claimed that many pensioners were bludgers.
verb If someone bludgeons you, they strike you with a heavy object. He was bludgeoned to death by his attackers.
adjective Something that is blue is the same colour as the sky and the sea on a sunny day. The sky was blue and cloudless. She's got blue eyes.
noun Blue is the name of that colour. Blue is my favourite colour.
adjective In informal language, if you say you feel blue, you mean you feel sad and depressed. I don't know why, but I just feel really blue today.
noun In informal language, if you say that you have a blue with someone, you mean that you have a disagreement or argument with them. Tony and Karl had a terrible blue.
noun A blue is also an informal word for a mistake. I made a real blue and deleted a whole file on the computer without meaning to.
Blue In Australia, people often use Blue as a nickname for someone with red hair.

out of the blue You say something happens out of the blue if it happens suddenly and unexpectedly. I'd completely lost touch with him when one day he phoned me out of the blue and asked me to go fishing with him.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See blues.

form.definition: noun A bluebottle is an animal which floats in the sea and has long trailing tentacles that can sting you badly.
adjective A blue-collar worker is someone who does manual work rather than working in an office.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is white-collar.

form.definition: noun Blue metal is rock that has been crushed into small pieces. It is used to make roads and as an ingredient in concrete.
noun A blue movie is a pornographic film.

noun A blueprint is a plan or outline for some project or or scheme. They're drawing up a blueprint for a new management structure. The government presented a blueprint for a better system of justice.
noun The blue-ringed octopus is an octopus with blue bands on its tentacles. It is found on the east coast of Australia. It is extremely dangerous and can kill humans with its bite.
noun The blues is a type of music with sad words and a slow rhythm. It was originally played by black people from the southern states of the USA.
noun In informal language, if you say you've got the blues, you mean you feel sad and depressed. Monday mornings always give me the blues.

verb If you bluff someone, you trick them by making them believe something that isn't true. The prisoner escaped by bluffing the guards that he had a loaded gun. I thought he was seriously hurt, but he was just bluffing.
noun A bluff is a high steep bank or cliff.

call someone's bluff If you call someone's bluff, you tell them to do what they are threatening to do because you are fairly sure that they won't actually do it. If you threaten to resign and they call your bluff it will be humiliating.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bluff Is his threat to resign serious, or just a bluff to get his own way?

form.definition: noun A blunder is a foolish mistake, usually with serious consequences. The battle was nearly lost because of a huge military blunder by the general in charge. Getting her name wrong was an unfortunate blunder.
verb If you blunder somewhere, you walk or move in a very clumsy way. I blundered through the dark room, stumbling over pieces of furniture. You can't just come blundering in without knocking first.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb blunder Someone's blundered and sent us the wrong order.

form.definition: adjective Something is blunt when it doesn't have a sharp edge or point. These scissors are getting very blunt. She was struck on the head with a blunt implement.
adjective You say someone is blunt when they speak very plainly and directly, without trying to be polite. To be quite blunt, I think the painting is awful. He was very blunt in his criticism.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb bluntly She spoke bluntly about her feelings. To put it bluntly, he lied.noun bluntness His bluntness was not appreciated.

form.definition: noun A blur is something unclear or confused. Without my glasses everything becomes a blur. I was so tired, the evening was just a blur.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective blurred Everything looks sort of blurred.verb blur (blurs, blurred, blurring) The rain had blurred the ink. My vision blurred and I felt faint.adjective blurry Suddenly everything went blurry.

form.definition: noun A blurb is information about a book or record, printed on its cover or in advertisements.

verb If you blurt something or blurt it out, you say it suddenly without thinking because you are nervous or excited. Peter suddenly blurted out his confession. 'I can't go on any longer', she blurted.
verb When you blush, your face becomes red because you're ashamed or embarrassed. Stacey blushed when the teacher praised her. I blush to remember how naive we were in those days.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun blush His declaration of love brought a blush to her cheeks.

form.definition: verb When someone blusters, they talk aggressively or boastfully, often because they are in an awkward situation. When the customs officer asked to inspect his suitcase, he began to bluster.
noun A BMX is a sturdy bicycle, good for riding on rough ground.
noun A board is a flat piece of wood. They nailed a board over the broken window.

noun A board is also a flat, rectangular piece of hard material that you use for a special purpose. Use a cutting board so as not to scratch the table. 3 noun The board of a company or organisation is the group of people who are in control. The school board voted to appoint a new principal.
verb When you board a ship, train, bus or plane, you get on it in order to go somewhere.
verb If you board at someone's house or at a hotel, you pay for a room and meals. When I was a student, I boarded with an uncle of mine.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See boarder. noun board We offer bed and breakfast or full board.

form.definition: noun A boarder is a pupil who lives at a school during term. ... THE OPPOSITEof this is day pupil.
noun A boarder is also someone who pays to live and eat meals at a boarding house or another person's house. My aunt takes in boarders during the summer.
verb When someone boasts about something they own or have done, they talk about it with too much pride. She's always boasting about how clever her children are.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun boast My father's boast was that he could fix anything.adjective boastful adverb boastfully

form.definition: noun A boat is a small vessel you use for travelling across water. ...a sailing boat. ...a motor boat. ...a rowing boat. --boat people
noun Boat people are people from South-East Asia who have left their countries because of war or political oppression. They come to Australia in small boats that are usually overcrowded.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor these people is refugees.

dictionary.entry:
bobbObbobsbobbedbobbing 1 verb When something bobs, it moves up and down quickly. The small sailing boat bobbed wildly in the large waves. I could see the dancers' heads bobbing
noun A bob is a short, neat haircut for women. My sister wears her hair in a bob.
bob up If someone or something bobs up, they appear or reappear suddenly. We hadn't seen our cat for days, but he bobbed up again this morning, thank goodness.

form.definition: noun A bobbin is a small reel that you wind cotton onto and use in a sewing machine.
noun A bobby pin is a thin piece of metal bent back on itself to form a clamp which holds your hair in place.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is hairpin.

form.definition: noun The bodice of a woman's dress is the part above the waist. I want something with a fitted bodice and full sleeves.
noun Your body is your whole physical structure. After the fun run, my whole body ached.

noun Your body is also your main physical part, not including your head, arms or legs. Another word for this is trunk. 2 noun A body is also a dead person or animal. It is their corpse or remains. Her body was discovered three days later.
noun The body of something is its main part. The car's body was badly dented. The recommendations made in the body of the report are summarised at the end.
noun A body is also a group of people who work together to run or manage something. She represents the parents on the school's governing body. The committee is an elected body with seven members.

noun A body is also a large amount or quantity of something. The oceans are vast bodies of water. I've collected a large body of information for my essay. It's impossible for anyone to master the whole body of scientific knowledge.
noun A bodyguard is a person or group of people whose job it is to protect someone.
noun A bog is an area of land which is very wet and muddy and in which you can get stuck.

bog down If you get bogged down, you get stuck in something which stops you from making any progress. Let's not get bogged down in discussing minor details. My application still hasn't been approvedit seems to have got bogged down in red tape.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb bog (bogs, bogged, bogging) Our car got bogged in the mud and we needed a tractor to pull it out.adjective boggy Don't drive over that boggy ground you'll get stuck!

form.definition: adjective Something that is bogus is untrue or not genuine. She came up with some completely bogus story about having to visit her sister. He tried to sell us some bogus shares. It all sounds pretty bogus to me!
noun A bogy is something that frightens or worries you. The dark is a real bogy for some small children. The Opposition is trying to raise the bogy of increased taxation.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is bogey (plural .

form.definition: verb When you boil a liquid, you heat it until it becomes so hot it starts to bubble and change into steam. When a liquid boils, it does this. Boil the water to kill off any bacteria in it. Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius.
verbWhen you boil food, you cook it in water that is boiling. Boil the potatoes for 20 minutes and they should be ready.

verb When you boil the kettle, you heat it until the water inside it boils. When the kettle boils, this is what happens. Would you like a cup of tea? I'm just boiling the kettle. This kettle switches itself off when it boils.

verb If you boil with anger, you are extremely angry. Joe's rudeness made me boil. My brother was boiling with rageI almost thought he was going to hit me. 5 noun A boil is an infected sore which forms under your skin. It contains pus and can be very painful.
boil over (a) If something you are boiling boils over, the liquid in the container rises and flows over the side of the pot or saucepan. Watch the milk carefully so it doesn't boil over.
(b) We say someone's feelings boil over if they lose their temper and become extremely angry. She suddenly boiled over and began shouting at us all.
noun A boiler is a large container in which steam or hot water is produced. This provides the energy to drive engines or to heat buildings.
noun A boilersuit is a set of protective overalls with long sleeves which you wear when you're doing heavy or dirty work.
adjective You say someone is boisterous when they are noisy, rough and full of energy. The pupils became boisterous when the teacher left the room. Gian bought home a boisterous young puppy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb boisterously

form.definition: adjective Someone who is bold is not afraid to do things. Leaving home at sixteen was a bold thing to do. Li Ling was bold enough to stand up for her friends in the argument.
adjective You also say someone is bold when they are rude or insolent. Don't speak to me in that bold voice.
adjective If a colour or pattern is bold, it is bright and easily noticed. Virginia stands out in a crowd; she always wears dresses with bold colours and designs.
adjective When printed letters are in bold type, they are thicker and blacker than the other letters around them.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb boldly noun boldness

form.definition: verb When something bolsters you, it helps you and makes you feel stronger or more confident. Doing well in the first race bolstered Donna's confidence for the second one.[qr

dictionary.entry:
boltb@Ult
noun A bolt is a sliding metal bar which you use to fasten a door or window.
noun A bolt is also a thick piece of metal without a point that is used to fasten together pieces of wood or metal. It passes through holes in the two layers and is secured on the other side with a nut. The motor is held in place by four strong bolts. 3 noun A bolt is also a sudden flash of lightning. We could see bolts of lightning as the storm approached.
verb If you bolt, you suddenly run away, to escape something. The prisoner saw his chance and bolted. The horse suddenly bolted and threw me to the ground.
verb If you bolt your food or bolt it down, you eat it very quickly. Sit still and don't bolt your food! She can bolt down a whole box of chocolates at a single sitting.
... WORD FAMILY verb bolt Make sure you bolt the windows before you go on holidays.

form.definition: noun A bomb is a container filled with explosives that is used as a weapon to destroy buildings and kill people.
noun In informal language, a bomb is also an old car which is in a bad condition. When I was a student all I could afford to drive was a bomb.

In informal language, if you say something goes like a bomb, you mean it goes very fast or very successfully. This new computer goes like a bomb compared to the one I had before. Katrin's party went like a bomb.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb bomb The villages had been repeatedly bombed from the air.

form.definition: verb When soldiers bombard a place, they keep attacking it with guns or bombs. The port was bombarded for two weeks. 2 verb If you bombard someone with questions or criticisms, you keep asking them questions or criticising them intensively, without giving them a chance to reply properly. Don't all bombard me at once. I'll take your questions one at a time. The minister has been bombarded with press criticism over the decision. ... WORD FAMILY noun bombardment ...a heavy aerial bombardment.
noun A bombshell is a great and unexpected surprise or shock. The retrenchments came as a bombshell to meI thought our company was doing pretty well.
adjective In formal or legal language, if something is bona fide, it is real or genuine. The hotel's swimming pool is only for the use of bona fide guests.

bona fides If you present your bona fides to someone who wants to know more about you, you give them evidence that you are genuine and that your intentions are honest and sincere. The police accepted his bona fides and released him.
noun A bond is something which joins or unites people. I've always felt a strong bond between Greg and me. The birth of their first child strengthened the bond of marriage.
verb If you bond two things, you glue them together. If two things bond, they become stuck or mixed together. 3 noun A bond is a written promise or agreement, often to do a job or to pay money.

noun A bond is also a certificate that the government or a bank gives you when you lend them money. In it, they promise to pay the money back to you, with interest, after a fixed time. One of the safest ways to invest your money is to buy government bonds.

bond money When you rent or lease something, you often have to pay bond money to cover the cost of any damage you may cause. If you finish the lease and return it on time without damage, you will get your money back. We had to pay $500 bond money when we rented the house. We only got $450 back because we damaged one of the beds.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bond For a firm bond, allow the glue to harden overnight.

form.definition: noun Your bones are the pieces of hard tissue inside your body that make up your skeleton. Rosanna fell over in the playground and broke a bone in her arm. Our dog just loves to chew on a bone.
verb When you bone a piece of meat or fish, you remove the bones from it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bone ...a knife with a bone handle.

form.definition: noun A bonfire is a large fire you make outside, either for pleasure or to burn unwanted things.

dictionary.entry: bongo`bONg@Ubongosbongoes noun Bongos are a pair of small drums that you hold between your knees and play by beating them with your fingers.

form.definition: noun The bonnet of your car is the metal lid which covers the engine. See the picture at car. He asked the mechanic to check under the bonnet.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this, especially in the USA, is hood.

form.definition: noun A bonnet is also a hat tied under the chin, usually worn by babies.

noun A bonus is something, usually pleasant, you receive in addition to getting something else. If you buy three books you'll get a fourth as a bonus. I wasn't expecting Graham to be there, so seeing him as well was a real bonus.
noun A bonus is also extra money given to you by your employer as a reward for good work.
noun Boob is an informal word for a woman's breast.
noun A boobook is a small brown owl with a white-spotted back and wings. It lives in Australia and New Zealand.
noun You win the booby prize in a competition when you come last.
noun A booby trap is a hidden or disguised trap or bomb which you set off when you disturb it. The soldiers forced their prisoners to walk ahead of them in case of booby traps.
noun A book is a set of pages bound together in a cover. You use books for reading or for writing in.

verb If you book a table at a restaurant, or seats at a cinema or theatre, or tickets to travel, you reserve a place in advance. In some cases you also pay in advance. We booked our holiday six months in advance. I'd like to book a table for two at eight o'clock, please. You need to book several days ahead to get in on a Friday evening.
verb If police officers book you, they take your name and address in order to charge you with an offence. The police officer booked Paolo for speeding and driving dangerously.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun booking I'd better make a booking at the restaurant.

form.definition: noun A bookcase is a set of shelves made of wood or metal where you keep books.
noun The job of bookkeeping involves keeping a record of all the money a business earns and spends.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bookkeeper

form.definition: noun Bookmakers are the people who take your money when you bet on a horse or dog in a race. If you win the bet, they will pay you the money you have won.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bookmaking

form.definition: noun A bookstall is a place where books are sold, for instance at an airport or at a railway station.
noun A bookworm is someone who loves to read.
verb When something booms, it makes a deep loud echoing sound. His voice boomed through the hall. The waves were booming in the cave.

noun A boom is a time when there is a sudden and rapid increase or development in something. Australia experienced a boom in the export of minerals during the 1970s. How can we break the economic cycle of boom and bust?

noun A boom is the long horizontal pole made of wood or metal that is attached to the mast of a sailing boat to keep the bottom of the sail straight. Keep your head down as we turn, or you'll get hit by the boom as it swings to the other side.
noun A boom is also any long pole that is moved for a special purpose, such as to hold a microphone in a film or TV studio, or to act as an entry gate for cars in a parking area.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb boom Business is booming.

form.definition: noun A boomer is a large male kangaroo.
noun A boomerang is a curved flat piece of wood that returns to you if you throw it in the right way. Boomerangs were first used by the Australian Aborigines as hunting weapons.

noun A boon is something very helpful or useful that makes life better or easier for you. Having a washing machine is a real boon. No more hard hand washing. Getting a lift from Adele was a real boonI was home half an hour earlier.
noun A boor is someone who is rude and inconsiderate.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis with bore. ... WORD FAMILY adjective boorish

form.definition: verb If you boost something, you lift it or increase it. Franco boosted the little girl up onto the high wall. The drop in interest rates will boost the economy.
verb If something boosts your confidence or spirits, it makes you feel better or happier. Good weather always boosts my morale. Getting a good mark for my essay did a lot to boost my self-esteem.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun boost Getting a place on the training course was a real boost.

form.definition: noun A boot is a sturdy shoe that covers your whole foot and ankle, and often the lower part of your leg.
noun The boot of your car is the enclosed space, usually at the back, where you can put luggage and shopping. The spare tyre and the jack are in the boot.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat car.

form.definition: verb If you boot something, you kick it. He booted the ball right over to the other side of the field.
verb If you boot or boot up a computer, you switch it on and make it ready to work.

boot out If you are booted out of a place, you are forced to leave. If you keep behaving like that, the security officer will boot you out of here. They're being booted out of their unit next month and they haven't found anywhere else yet.
get the boot If you get the boot from your job, you are given the sack. You are fired. Natasha got the boot for always coming to work late.
noun A booth is a small enclosed compartment usually only big enough for one person, such as a telephone booth or a polling booth at an election.
noun A booth is also a tent or stall at a market or fair in which things are displayed that you can buy. There were many more booths at the boat show this year than last.
noun Booty is a collection of valuable things either stolen by thieves or taken by soldiers after a battle, or simply won as a prize.
noun Booze is an informal word for alcoholic drink. I'll have to lay off the booze tonightI've got to drive home.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb booze She'd already been boozing for three hours.noun boozer He's a real boozerlook at his red nose.

form.definition: noun A border is the boundary line that separates one country or state from another. Albury is right on the border of New South Wales and Victoria.
noun A border is also an edge or side of something. Could you get me the white plate with a gold border?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb border Western Australia borders Northern Territory and South Australia.

form.definition: noun The borderline is the boundary or dividing line between two things. Omar was on the borderline between passing and failing the driving test.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective borderline He got a borderline pass in the exam.

form.definition: verb If you bore a hole in something, you make a round hole in it, sometimes with a drill. Another word for this is drill. The termites bored holes in the timber. To reach the gold, the miners had to bore through solid rock.
noun A bore is a deep hole drilled into the earth to reach a supply of water under the ground. Bores are the only source of water for many cattle stations in the outback.
verb If something bores you, you find it dull and uninteresting. Mathematics has always bored me rigid. Clarice insisted on boring us all with tales of her holiday.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bore I got stuck with a real bore at the party. Washing up is such a bore. adjective bored What shall I do now, mum? I'm bored! ...a bored expression.adjective boring The journey was long and boring. Ted's really boringhe's got no personality.noun boredom We spent hours of boredom waiting for her. ...a look of boredom on his face.

form.definition: verb When someone is born, their mother gives birth to them. Vin-Zu was born on 27 October 1988. When she was born, she had masses of black hair and dark brown eyes.
verb You say something is born when it comes into existence. When all parties had signed the treaty, the new state was born.

adjective When you say someone is a born musician, cook, teacher, fool and so on, you mean they have had that talent or characteristic from the time they were born. Dan's a born comedianhe's always been able to make people laugh.
verb Borne is the past tense of bear.
noun A boronia is an Australian native shrub with small brown or pink flowers.
noun A borough is an area of land in Victoria similar to a municipality in the other states of Australia.

verb If you borrow something from someone, you are allowed to use it for a while with the understanding that you will give it back to them later. You can borrow up to five books at a time from the library. May I borrow your pen for a moment?
form.note: ... COMPAREthis word with lend. If you lend something to someone, you give it to them for a while because they want to borrow it.

form.definition: noun Someone's bosom is their chest. The word is used especially when talking about a woman's breasts. She clasped the child protectively to her bosom.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective bosomy ...a bosomy young model.

form.definition: noun Your boss is the person you work foryour employer or your immediate superior at work. I'm not sure if I can get time offI'll have to ask my boss. What's your new boss like?
verb If you boss someone around, you give orders to them in an unpleasant way. Don't try to boss me aroundI'm older and wiser than you! Meredith tends to boss the younger children.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective bossy (bossier, bossiest) She annoyed us all by being so bossy. He sent round a bossy memo about noise.

form.definition: noun A botanist is someone who knows a lot about plant life.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun botany

form.definition: verb If you botch something, you spoil or ruin it because of your carelessness or lack of skill. Roger botched last night's dinnerit was completely overcooked. ... WORD FAMILY noun botch He made a real botch of repairing the car.
adjective We use both to refer to two things together. You should clean both shoes before you go out.
pronoun Both can stand for two things or two people. Both want to come to the party. I'll send both in the mail.[xp\start\[ap--bother

verb If someone or something bothers you, they disturb you. I can't even read the paper for five minutes without the kids bothering me. It's not too painfulI hardly like to bother the doctor with it. Is the light bothering you?
verb If something bothers you, it worries or confuses you. Being late for work always bothers me. There's one thing still bothering me: how did the murderer know she'd be there that night?

verb If you bother to do something, you make the effort needed to do it. I can't be bothered to cook tonight. I didn't bother washing my hair. 'Can I give you a hand?' 'Oh, please don't bother.' She was so pleased that I was glad I'd bothered to go.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bother 'Would you like a lift?' 'Yes, please, if you're sure it's not a bother.'adjective bothersome It's not really painful, but it's bothersome.

form.definition: noun A bottle is a container for holding liquids. It is usually made of glass or plastic, and is shaped like a cylinder with a narrow top. ...a milk bottle. ...a bottle of wine. The baby hasn't finished its bottle. He drank half a bottle of whisky. I need to buy a bottle to take to Sue's dinner party.
verb When you bottle wine or some other liquid, you put it into bottles. When you bottle fruit, you put it into bottles or jars to preserve it.
3 bottle shop A bottle shop is a place where you can buy alcohol to drink somewhere else. Most hotels have bottle shops.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective bottled ...bottled milk.

form.definition: noun A bottlebrush is an Australian native shrub whose flower spikes look like a brush.
noun A bottleneck is a narrow part of a road which slows down traffic. There's a real bottleneck where the road changes from three lanes to two.
noun A bottleneck is also a place or stage in a process which slows down progress. These slow old machines are the cause of the production bottleneck.

noun The bottom of something is its base or lowest part. The opposite of this is top. The ship sank to the bottom of the ocean. My shoes are in the bottom of the cupboard. Sign your name at the bottom of the page. The village lies at the bottom of the hill.

noun If you are at the bottom of an organisation, group or class, you are at the lowest level. She started at the bottom and worked her way up to be head of the department. We want to help those at the bottom of society.

noun Your bottom is the part of your body you sit on. Another word for this is buttocks. See the picture at body. I fell flat on my bottom. The surface was a smooth as a baby's bottom. These jeans are too tight round the bottom.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective bottom It's in the bottom drawer. They put me in the bottom class.

form.definition: noun A bough is one of the large main branches of a tree.
verb Bought is the past tense and past participle of buy.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis with brought, which is the past tense and past participle of bring.

form.definition: noun A boulder is a very large rock, especially one with a round shape.
noun A boulevard is a long wide avenue or street in a city, usually with trees growing along each side.
verb When a ball bounces, it immediately springs back after it hits the ground or a wall. The ball bounced once before disappearing into the bush.
verb If you bounce a ball, you throw it against a surface to make it spring back towards you. She was bouncing a ball against the wall.
verb If a cheque bounces, the bank does not accept it because the person who wrote it doesn't have enough money in their bank account to pay for it.

bounce back If you bounce back after being ill or having a bad experience, you return to your previous level of health or happiness. It was good to see him bounce back after being so ill. After each defeat it gets harder and harder to bounce back.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bounce Hit the ball before the second bounce.

form.definition: adjective A bouncing baby is one that is healthy and strong. She gave birth to a bouncing boy.
adjective A bouncy person is someone who is always cheerful and active. Salim will be a great teacherhe's got such a bouncy personality.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bounciness

form.definition: verb Bound is the past tense and past participle of bind.
adjective If you are bound by an agreement, contract or law, you have a duty to obey it. We're bound by the contract to pay him. You are legally bound to tell the truth in court.

adjective If you say something is bound to happen, you mean it is certain to happen. Those black clouds mean it's bound to rain. If she's not at home, she's bound to be at the office. Ask Aleche's bound to know. There's bound to be a direct flight.

adjective If you are bound for a certain place, you are going there or intend to go there. She was on her way to the airport, bound for Sydney. This train is bound for Perth. In January I'm bound for Fiji.
verb If you bound, you move along quickly by taking big steps or leaps. He bounded eagerly after her. The kangaroo bounded across the grass.

bounded by When an area of land is bounded by something, its boundaries or limits are marked out by that thing. The prison grounds were bounded by a high wall and barbed wire. NSW is bounded by Victoria in the south, South Australia in the west, and Queensland in the north.

bounds The bounds of something are its limits. They were lost somewhere within the bounds of Kosciusko National Park. This goes beyond the bounds of what is reasonable. Their enthusiasm knew no bounds.

bound up in If you are bound up in something, you are very busy with it or interested in it, so that you are not able to give attention to other things. He doesn't have a social lifehe's totally bound up in his work. Don't get bound up in detail, or you won't have time to cover the whole topic.

bound up with If something is bound up with something else, they are dependent on each other or are closely connected with each other. My future career prospects are bound up with this course. Educational disadvantage is often bound up with poverty.
out of bounds If a place is out of bounds to you, you are not allowed to go there. Certain parts of the school buildings are out of bounds to the students.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bound He cleared the ditch with one giant bound.

form.definition: noun The boundary of an area of land is the line that separates it from another area. The Murray River forms the boundary between NSW and Victoria. He hit the cricket ball clear over the boundary.
noun A bounty is a reward or payment which is given to you for a special purpose. The farmers were given a bounty of $5 for every wild pig they shot.
noun A bouquet is a specially chosen and arranged bunch of flowers, often given as a present. The bride carried a magnificent white and pink bouquet.
noun The bouquet of a wine is its smell. Any really good wine should have a rich bouquet.
noun If you say that something is bourgeois, you mean that it is typical of the way of life of the middle classes. Often you mean that it is conventional and boring.

noun A bout is a short period of time in which something happens intensively. We've had a bout of heavy rain lately. Don't try to do too much in one bout. In a bout of enthusiasm I cleaned the whole house.
noun A bout is also a period of illness. I had a nasty bout of flu last week. He missed a lot of school with bouts of pneumonia.
noun A bout is also a sporting contest that involves a fight between individual competitors, for example in boxing, wrestling and fencing. He won ten out of his twelve professional bouts.
noun A boutique is a small shop where you can buy expensive and fashionable clothes, shoes or jewellery, especially for women.[qr

dictionary.entry:
bowb@U for definitions 1-3;
noun A bow is a knot with two loops and two loose ends. You use it to tie shoe laces or ribbons.
noun A bow is also a weapon you use to shoot arrows. It is a long thin strip of wood bent in a curve by a piece of string stretched between the ends.
noun The bow of a violin or other stringed instrument is made of long strands of horse's hair stretched along a piece of wood. You move the bow across its strings to make the sound. 4 noun The bow of a ship or boat is its pointed front part. The opposite of this is stern.
verb When you bow, you bend the top part of your body forward. You do this as a very formal greeting or to show respect. Actors and musicians also do it to acknowledge applause.
bow out If you bow out of something, you stop taking part in it. The minister announced his intention to bow out at the next election.
bow to If you bow to something, you reluctantly accept its control over your actions. I still don't agree, but I'll bow to the wishes of the majority. He competed well for many years, but eventually had to bow to increasing age. I won't bow to their demands!
... WORD FAMILY noun bow He welcomed her with a low bow. Jenny should take a bow for all her hard work.

form.definition: noun Your bowel is the long tube in your body which carries digested food from your stomach out through your anus. The word is often used in its plural form, bowels.
