Another word for it is intestine. She had a large cancer removed from her lower bowel. Have you had any trouble with your bowels lately?
noun A bowerbird is an Australian bird. The males build large decorative structures, often decorated with coloured objects that they have collected, in order to attract the females to be their mates.
noun You call someone a bowerbird if they collect a lot of useless objects. Daniel's a real bowerbirdhis garage is so full of things that he can't get his car in.

noun A bowl is a deep round dish that you use for serving food or for mixing things when you cook. Combine the ingredients in a medium-sized bowl. ...a soup bowl. ...a cereal bowl. ...a salad bowl. The flowers were arranged in a shallow bowl.

noun You can also use bowl to describe the amount of food or liquid contained in a bowl. The prisoners were given just one bowl of rice a day. She ate three bowls of ice-cream. 2 noun You also use bowl to describe something which is shaped like a bowl. ...the bowl of a spoon. ...a wash bowl. ...a toilet bowl. The village lay in the bowl of the hills.
verb When you bowl in cricket, you throw the ball towards the person who is batting, to give them a chance to hit it.
verb If you bowl the person who is batting in a game of cricket, you get them out by hitting their wicket.
verb If you bowl in the game of bowls or in bowling, you roll a ball along the ground or along the track.
bowl over (a) If you bowl someone over, you accidentally knock them to the ground by running into them. The dog dashed off, almost bowling Jake over.
(b) If someone or something bowls you over, you are very surprised or impressed by them. Ten-Hu was bowled over when he heard he'd got the job.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bowlful noun bowler Australia's bowlers worried the English batsmen in the second Test.noun See bowling. noun See bowls.

form.definition: noun Bowling is an indoor game in which you roll a large black ball down a narrow wooden track and try to knock over bottle-shaped wooden objects.
noun Bowling is also another word for the game of bowls.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective bowling ...a bowling alley.adjective bowling ...a bowling club. ...a bowling green. ...bowling shoes.

form.definition: noun Bowls is an outdoor game played on very smooth grass. The object of the game is to roll a large black ball as close as possible to a small white ball. People usually wear white or cream-coloured clothing and special shoes to play bowls.
noun A bowser is a petrol pump at a service station where you go to fill up your car with petrol.

noun A box is a square or rectangular container made of wood or cardboard. Usually it has a lid. I'm moving next week, so I need a lot of boxes for packing. She bought a beautiful enamelled box in Thailand. ...a box of matches. The glasses are $5 each, or $25 for a box of six.
noun You can also use box to describe the amount contained in a box. No wonder you feel sick if you ate a whole box of chocolates! How many boxes of envelopes do we get through in a year?
noun A very small room or enclosed space can also be called a box. ...a telephone box. ...the witness box. They've put me in a box near the admissions office.
noun A box at a theatre or concert hall is a small enclosed area with a few seats in it, usually at an upper level and to the side. They usually reserve a box at the opera to entertain their guests.
noun In informal language, the box is another word for television. What's on the box tonight?
noun A box is also a printed square or rectangle on a form in which you have to write something. Please tick one box only. Don't forget to sign in the box on page four.

verb When you box with someone, you hit or punch each other with closed fists, often as an arranged sporting event. Julio was asked to box in the exhibition bout before the main event. 7 verb If you box someone's ear, you hit them sharply on the ear with your hand or fist.

box in When you are boxed in, you are stuck or caught in a small space. You are surrounded by things that won't allow you to leave easily. I couldn't get out of the car park because I was boxed in by other cars. Quang felt really boxed in when he moved to a city flat. We haven't got much choicethey've boxed us in.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See boxer. noun boxing Many medical practitioners believe boxing should be banned.noun box Navin gave him a box on the ear.

form.definition: noun A boxer is a dog with short hair, a flat snout and a very short tail.
noun A boxer is also someone who fights with their fists as a sport. Mohammed Ali is perhaps the most famous boxer of all time.
noun A box jellyfish is a type of jellyfish you find in the seas off northern Queensland and the Northern Territory between October and April. Its sting is very dangerous and can kill you.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is stinger.

form.definition: noun The box office is the place at a theatre or concert hall where you can buy tickets for the performances.
noun A boy is a male child. They had a large familyfour girls and three boys. My eldest boy's away at college now.
noun You can also use boy to refer to a young man. She married a local boy. He seemed a typical boy next doorI never guessed he'd become a famous actor.

boys You can also use boys to refer to a group of men. Seb likes to have a night out with the boys once a week. I want to discuss the idea with the boys in marketing. There's plenty of beer in the fridge, boys!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective boyish At thirty, he still seemed awkward and boyish. Don't trust his boyish charm.

form.definition: verb If you boycott something, you refuse to take part or be involved in it, as a way of showing your disapproval or opposition. We're going to boycott the company until they stop selling unsafe products to African countries.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun boycott

form.definition: noun Your boyfriend is the boy or young man you go out on dates with.
noun A bra is a piece of underwear women wear to support their breasts.[qr

dictionary.entry:
bracebrEIs
noun A brace is a metal part which holds things together or in place. The braces have come loose and the machine is unsteady.
noun A brace is also something you attach to a part of your body to support it. Nabil has to wear a brace because of his weak back. ...a neck brace. 2a verb If you brace something, you physically support or strengthen it. We'd better brace that book shelf to keep it steady.
verb If you brace yourself for something difficult or unpleasant, you prepare yourself for it. We braced ourselves for the bad news.
braces (a) Braces are wires which a dentist may stretch across your teeth to straighten them. The orthodontist fitted Maria with braces. (b) Braces are also elastic straps that are attached to the back and front of trousers and extend over the shoulders to hold the trousers up.

form.definition: noun A bracelet is a chain or band you wear around your wrist as jewellery.
noun Bracken is a coarse fern that grows in areas that have a lot of rain. In some areas it has become a pest.
noun A bracket is a right-angled piece of metal, wood or plastic that you fasten to a wall to support a shelf.

noun If you say that someone or something is in a particular bracket, you mean that they belong to a particular group or range. This income may take you into a higher tax bracket. Most of our clients are drawn from the middle-income bracket. Their scores were mostly within the 50%-70% bracket.

brackets Brackets are a pair of written marks, such as ( ) or ;ob;cb, that you use to put around words to show you are adding extra information. I added my surname in brackets, in case the teacher had forgotten me.

dictionary.entry: bragbrAgbragsbraggedbragging verb If someone brags, they talk proudly about themselves, their possessions or their achievements. Franz is always bragging about how well he skis. ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is boast.

form.definition: verb If you braid several lengths of hair or thread, you twist them together in a decorative pattern. Another word for this is plait. She used to wear her hair braided on the top of her head.
noun Braid is a narrow band or tape of twisted threads which is used to decorate clothes, uniforms or upholstery. The captain's hat was trimmed with gold braid.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun braid She wore her hair in a thick braid.

form.definition: noun Braille is a form of printing that blind people can read by touch. It is made up of raised dots arranged in a special pattern for each letter.
noun Your brain is the mass of grey nerve tissue inside your skull which controls your body and enables you to think. We still don't know how the human brain works.
noun You can call someone a brain if they are very intelligent and clever. Shelley's a real brainshe always does well in exams. The best brains in the country have failed to solve the problem.

brains If you say someone has brains, you mean they are very intelligent and clever. Leon must have brains to have scored so well in that test. I haven't got the brains to go to university. Jackie was the one with the brains in our family.
on the brain If you have something on the brain, you can't stop thinking about it. Ever since I heard it this morning, I've had that stupid song on the brain.

pick someone's brains If you pick someone's brains, you use their knowledge or skill to help you do a job. I want to pick your brains about grammar for this assignment I've got to do. Harry knows a lot about engineswhy don't you pick his brains?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective brainy (brainier, brainiest) Judy's very brainyshe can always finish the crossword.

form.definition: verb If a group of people brainstorm, they try to find a solution to a problem by all thinking of as many different ideas as they can.

verb If you brainwash someone, you make them believe something by forcing them to listen to your ideas all the time, and not allowing them to think about other things. The speaker accused the cult of brainwashing young people by using techniques such as sleep deprivation. You soon become brainwashed into thinking like everyone else in the company.
noun A brainwave is a sudden brilliant idea. I've had a brainwavewhy don't we use the wire from the hangers? Zoltan's brainwave helped us finish in half the time.
verb If you braise meat, you fry it quickly, then cook it slowly in a covered saucepan. You can also braise vegetables.
noun A brake is a device for slowing down or stopping a vehicle or a machine, or for preventing it from moving.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis with break. ... WORD FAMILY verb brake I had to brake hard to avoid the dog.

form.definition: noun Bran is the outer skin of various grains, such as wheat, which is left over after the grains have been crushed to make flour. It is often used as an ingredient in breakfast cereals.
noun A branch of a tree or bush is a stem that grows out from the trunk. The big storm brought down a lot of dead branches.

noun A branch is also a part of something that divides off from the main part as it goes along. This creek is a branch of the main river running through town. The telephone cable splits into two branches here.

noun A branch is also a part or section of an organisation or something structured. Our company has branches in all Australian capital cities. What branch of psychology do you specialise in? Jean belongs to the Newcastle branch of our family.

branch off If a road or river branches off, it divides and goes in two or more different directions. The road branched off, and we didn't know which path to follow. The trainees all study together for the first six weeks, and then they branch off into various departments.
branch out If you branch out, you add to your range of activities or interests. We've decided to branch out into selling sporting goods. You need to branch out a bitwhy don't you join a social club?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb branch The river branches just around the bend.

form.definition: noun A brand is a mark or label on something which tells you who made it or where it was made.
noun A brand is also a product made by a particular company or manufacturer. Which brand of beer do you like? You can expect to pay more for a well-known brand.
verb If you brand an animal, you burn a mark on its skin to show it belongs to you. All Mike's cattle are branded with his initialsMH.

adjective You say someone is brash when they are overconfident and behave in an arrogant way. They sent a brash young manager who upset most of the staff. Jenny's rather loud and brash, but she means well.
noun Brass is a yellow metal made by mixing copper and zinc. ...a heavy old door knocker made of brass.
noun The brass in a band or an orchestra are the instruments such as trumpets and horns.
noun Brassiere is a formal word for bra.

noun Brat is an informal and unfriendly word for a child, especially a child who annoys you because of its bad behaviour. I wish those brats next door would stop yelling. Their daughter's a real spoiled brat.
noun Bravado is a show of bravery or confidence that someone displays in order to impress other people. Eva was full of bravado before she went to see the boss, but really she was very nervous.
adjective You are brave if you are willing to do something that is dangerous, or to suffer pain and discomfort without complaining.
verb If you brave something unpleasant or dangerous, you endure it instead of avoiding it. We braved the cold and went swimming anyway.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb bravely She bravely stood up and told the crowd what she thought.noun bravery He showed great bravery in the face of danger.

form.definition: noun A brawl is a noisy fight or quarrel. He got a black eye and a broken nose in the brawl. We were disturbed at three in the morning by a drunken brawl outside.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb brawl They were brawling in the street.

form.definition: noun Brawn is boiled meat from the head of a pig which is pressed into a mould so that it sets into a jelly. You can eat it with salads or in sandwiches.
noun Someone who has brawn is strong and has well-developed muscles. His bodyguards clearly had more brawn than brains.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective brawny (brawnier, brawniest) He's a brawny former boxer.

form.definition: adjective If someone is brazen, they behave in a bold and shameless way. His brazen behaviour got him into a lot of trouble. She was completely brazen about having cheated in the examination.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb brazenly He brazenly lied about being involved, in spite of the evidence.

form.definition: verb If you breach a contract, agreement or law, you fail to obey it. Amal is threatening to sue us for breaching our contract with him. These large companies are breaching the laws on pollution control daily.
noun A breach is a crack or opening in a wall or barrier.
noun A breach is also a break in a friendship or relationship.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun breach You are in breach of the agreement between us.verb breach

form.definition: noun Bread is a common food made by baking a mixture of flour, water, and usually yeast. The bread's a bit stale, but we can use it for toast. ...a loaf of bread. ...a slice of bread.
noun Bread is also an informal word for money. I'm really short of bread this month.

adjective A bread-and-butter issue is one which is concerned with the everyday matters that are necessary to life. Most ordinary people are more concerned with bread-and-butter issues such as housing than with international affairs. She gained a reputation as a bread-and-butter local politician.

If someone is on the breadline, they are so poor that they hardly have enough money to buy the food that they need. Muoi and Quang were on the breadlineneither of them could find a job. You don't know what it's like living on the breadline.

noun The breadth of something is the distance from one of its sides to the other. It is how broad the thing is. Another word for this is width. The package is 20 cm in height, 35 cm in breadth and 15 cm in depth. A fallen tree trunk lay across the whole breadth of the road.

noun Breadth can also refer to the range or scope of something. This is sometimes contrasted with depth. She showed enormous breadth of vision. I was impressed by the breadth of talent on display. His articles show breadth rather than depth of learning.

noun A breadwinner is someone who earns money to support other members of their family. The children had to leave school to become breadwinners. In the family of ten, there are only two breadwinners. We took it in turns to be the breadwinner while the other studied.

verb If something breaks, it separates into pieces, usually because it has been dropped or hit. The cup broke when it fell onto the tiled floor. I'm afraid I've broken a glass. Several of the windows were broken.
verb If you break a bone in your body, it cracks or separates into two or more pieces. John broke his leg in the motorbike accident. He was killed, but she got away with a few broken bones.
verb If you break an apparatus or piece of equipment, you damage it in some way so that it doesn't work any more. Peter borrowed my electric drill and broke itnow I'll have to get it repaired.
verb If someone breaks a rule or law, they don't obey it. If your employer pays you less than award rates, they are breaking the law.

verb If someone breaks a promise or agreement, they don't do what they promised or agreed to do. I said I'd be there, and I don't like to break my promises. If you leave before the end of the month you'll be breaking your contract.

verb If you break a record, for example in sport, you do better than the best performance so far. She broke the Australian record for the 100 metres backstroke. They broke the record for the greatest distance tunnelled in a single eight-hour shift.

verb If you break news to someone, you tell them what has happened. He gently broke the news to her that her father had died. I don't know how to break it to you, but Anwar's missing. The Age broke the news of his resignation in the late edition. 7 verb If you break a habit, you stop doing a particular thing that you usually do. It's hard to break the habit of smoking, but it's well worth the effort.

verb If something breaks someone, it destroys their success or ruins them in some way. The mortgage will break me if I can't get more work somehow. We all thought he would be prime minister soon, but the scandal broke him.

verb If something breaks an activity or some state, it ends it or interrupts it. A loud bang broke the silence. We broke our trip to Europe by stopping off in Singapore. Be sure and break your studying with plenty of fresh air and exercise.

verb If something breaks someone's heart, it makes them extremely unhappy. When Tasha died, it broke Vishal's heart. 11a verb If someone's voice breaks when they are speaking, they sound as if they are going to cry. Her voice would always break when she talked about Ted. The minister's voice broke, and he reached for a glass of water.
verb When a boy's voice breaks, it gets deeper because he is becoming a man. Evan's voice broke when he was only thirteen. 12 verb When a drought breaks, it ends because it begins to rain.
noun A break in routine or in the regular pattern of something is a change from what normally happens. The rain was a welcome break after all that hot dry weather we'd been having.
noun A break is also a short rest or holiday. Let's have a ten-minute break for coffee. We went away for a weekend break in the Blue Mountains.
noun A break is also a piece of luck or an opportunity. Getting that job was a lucky break for me. She got her big break when she won a scholarship to uni. Go on, give me a breaklend me $200.

break away (a) If you break away from someone, you move away from them suddenly with a quick decision. I suddenly realised how late it was and broke away from the conversation. The leading runners have broken away from the rest of the pack.

(b) If you break away from a group or organisation, you end your connection with them. I broke away from my family when I was sixteen. Several directors have broken away from Acme and set up a rival company.
break down (a) If a machine breaks down, it stops working because of a fault. This photocopier keeps breaking down.
(b) If discussions or negotiations break down, they end unsuccessfully because of a problem or disagreement. The peace talks broke down over the issue of timing.
(c) If someone breaks down, they can't prevent themselves from crying. Kim broke down and wept when he heard the news. I tried not to break down in front of them.

(d) If you break down a structure, you destroy it by knocking it down. The police entered the house by breaking down the door. We must break down the barriers between different sections of the community.

(e) If you break something down, you separate it into the different parts or substances of which it is composed. The acid in our stomach breaks down our food so that the body can use it. You should break your argument down into separate sections.

break even If you break even, your income is equal to your expenditure. You do not make either a profit or a loss. We should break even after three years, and make healthy profits after that. I'm just about breaking even and there's not a lot to spare.

break in (a) If you break in on a conversation or activity, you interrupt it. I'm sorry to break in, but I couldn't help hearing you mention my name. We'd just started the meeting when Tom broke in with the news of the fire.
(b) If you break in a horse, you tame it and make it get used to wearing a harness.
(c) If you break in a new pair of shoes or boots, you wear them to make them become less stiff and more comfortable.
break into (a) If someone breaks into a house or building, they enter it by force. Burglars broke into six houses in this area yesterday. Police had to break in to retrieve the body.

(b) If you say that someone breaks into laughter, into song or into a run, you mean that they suddenly start laughing, singing or running. Halfway through the speech, the audience broke into applause. The horse suddenly broke into a gallop.

(c) If you break into a new area of activity, you start to become involved in it, often experiencing difficulty in doing so. It took a long time for women to break into the engineering profession. We want to break into the lucrative home entertainment market.

break off (a) If you break off a part of something, you remove it by tearing or snapping it off. Can you break me off another piece of chocolate, please? The handle broke off when I picked the jug up.

(b) If you break off a relationship with someone else, you end it. Yolanda and Luis broke off their engagement after seven months. The President threatened to break off diplomatic relations because of the incident.

(c) If you break off what you are doing, you suddenly stop doing it. They broke off their conversation when I entered the room. Bill began his speech, but then broke off and said he was ill. She was forced to break off her studies when her mother died.
break out (a) When prisoners break out of gaol, they escape.
(b) If something such as war, fire or disease breaks out, it suddenly begins. A fire broke out in the plastics factory.

(c) If you break out in a rash or a sweat, your body becomes covered with a rash or with sweat. Ilde broke out in red spots all over her body. You should exercise hard enough to break out in a sweat. 22 break through If someone or something breaks through something, they get through it suddenly or by force. The sun broke through the clouds. The demonstrators broke through the line of police. 23 break up (a) If something breaks up, it separates into smaller pieces. In spring, the ice starts to break up and flow down the river. We'll have to break up the soil before we can plant anything.
(b) If something breaks up, it is destroyed because its components come apart. The satellite broke up on entering the earth's atmosphere. Lesley accused Shana of trying to break up her marriage.
(c) If you break up with your spouse or lover, you end the relationship. I broke up with Sadie last year. Have you heard? Rhona and Simon have broken up.

(d) When a school breaks up, the term ends and the students start their holidays. The schools break up on different dates in the various states. We break up for the summer next week. ... WORD FAMILY adjective See broken. noun breakage All breakages must be paid for.noun See breakdown. noun break-in Those six break-ins were all done by the same gang.noun breakout There was a breakout from the prison last night.noun See outbreak. noun See breakthrough. noun breakup It was a bitter breakup.
adjective If a thing is breakable, it can be easily broken. Be sure you pack all breakable objects carefully.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun breakables This carton's full of breakables.

form.definition: noun If something has a breakdown, it stops because of a mechanical failure or a problem. Our car had three breakdowns between Sydney and Darwin. There was a breakdown in talks between the unions and the employers. 2 noun A breakdown of something is a description of its separate parts. The accountant gave me a breakdown of the figures.
noun If someone has a breakdown, they suffer a physical or mental collapse so that they cannot cope with their usual daily activities.
noun Breakfast is the first meal you have after you get up in the morning. What time do you have breakfast?
noun A break-in is a burglary carried out by thieves who enter a building by force. There was a break-in at the office last night, and some of the computers are gone.

noun A breakthrough is an important discovery or advance which is made after a lot of hard work and usually a number of failures. This chance find gave police their first real breakthrough in the investigation.
noun A bream is an Australian edible fish that lives in salt water.
noun A woman's breasts are the two round, fleshy parts on her chest that can produce milk to feed a baby.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body.

form.definition: noun In formal language, breast can also mean someone's chest. He clasped his son fondly to his breast.
noun Breaststroke is a style of swimming in which you move your arms forwards, outwards and back from your chest while you move your legs like a frog.

noun Your breath is the air you take into your lungs and let out again when you breathe. I could feel her soft breath on my cheek. How long can you hold your breath? His breath was coming in sharp pants. Let me get my breath back. The sight took my breath away.
noun When you take a breath, you breathe in and out once. The doctor told me to take deep breaths. Every breath was painful.
noun A breath is also a very light current of air. We could feel a slight breath of cool air coming through the windows.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb See breathe. adjective breathless He was breathless after running up the steep hill. adjective breathy The child called my name in a breathy voice.

form.definition: noun A breathalyser is a machine the police use to measure the amount of alcohol in a driver's breath.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb breathalyse (or breathalyze) I got breathalysed on the way home.

form.definition: verb When you breathe, you draw air into your lungs and let it out again. If you feel sick, breathing deeply might make you feel better. When they got him out of the water, he'd stopped breathing.
verb If you breathe something, you say it very quietly or softly. He breathed her name in her ear.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun breathing His breathing was shallow and fasthe really was sick.

form.definition: adjective If you say something is breathtaking, you mean it is such an extreme example of its kind that it's quite surprising. We might also say that it takes our breath away. Her progress has been breathtaking. There's a breathtaking view from the top of the mountain.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb breathtakingly The view is breathtakingly beautiful.

form.definition: noun A breath test is a scientific analysis of someone's breath. It is often used by the police to see how much alcohol is in a person's bloodstream. Rowan failed the breathalyser test the police gave him after the accident, so he was taken to the police station for a breath test.

dictionary.entry:
breedbri:dbreedsbredbreeding 1 verb When animals breed, they mate and produce young. Rabbits breed extremely rapidly. Use disinfectant to clean areas where germs can breed. 2 verb If you breed animals or plants, you keep them so that they will produce more of their kind for you. He breeds budgerigars for a hobby. They've
verb In rather formal language, if you say that something breeds something undesirable, you mean that it causes it to develop. Garbage breeds disease. Violence breeds violence.
noun A breed of an animal is a particular type of it that has been deliberately developed. The merino is the most successful breed of sheep in Australia. What breed is your dog?

form.definition: noun A breeze is a light or gentle wind. The cool breeze was very welcome after the heat of the day.

verb If you say that someone breezes into a place, you mean they enter it in a careless and confident way. Every day Karen breezes into the office an hour lateshe'll be lucky not to lose her job. You can't just breeze in here like thatknock first.
noun In informal language, if you say something is a breeze, you mean it is very easy to learn or do. Warren thought the driving test was a breeze.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See breezy.

form.definition: adjective If the weather is breezy, there are breezes blowing. You'd better wear a jumperit's pretty breezy today.
adjective If a person is breezy, they are brisk and cheerful.
noun The brevity of something is the short time it lasts or takes. His speech was a masterpiece of brevity.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See brief.

form.definition: verb If you brew tea, you make it by pouring boiling water over tea leaves, then leaving the mixture to infuse. Let's brew a pot of tea.
verb If you say that something is brewing, you mean it is starting to develop. We could see a storm brewing on the horizon. There's trouble brewing with the unions.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See brewery.

form.definition: noun A brewery is a factory that produces beer.
verb If someone tries to bribe you, they offer to give you money or a valuable gift if you do something for them. He bribed the customs officer to turn a blind eye.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bribe Several police officers were accused of accepting bribes.noun bribery You must report any attempt at bribery.

form.definition: noun A brick is a hard rectangular block of baked clay that is used for building. One of the bricks has come loose from the wall. Our house is built of brick and tile.
brick up If you brick up a window or door, you fill in the opening by laying bricks. All the windows on that side of the house have been bricked up.
noun Brickie is an informal word for bricklayer.
noun A bricklayer is someone who is qualified to build houses and walls from bricks.
adjective A brick-veneer house has a timber frame and a single layer of bricks on the outside.
noun A bride is a woman who is about to be married, or has just been married.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective bridal They spent the first night of their honeymoon in the hotel's bridal suite.

form.definition: noun A bridegroom is a man who is about to be married, or has just been married.
noun A bridesmaid is a girl or woman who helps the bride on her wedding day and is one of the official group at the wedding ceremony. Joanne had three bridesmaids at her wedding.
noun A bridge is a structure built over a river or road so that people and vehicles can cross from one side to the other.

verb If you bridge a gap between two things, you take some action so that the two things become closer together. If you want to be friends again, both of you must be willing to bridge the gap. We need action to bridge the vast gap in prosperity between different levels of society.
noun The bridge of a ship is the room from which the captain and other officers navigate it.
noun The bridge of your nose is the bony upper part between your eyes.
noun Bridge is also a card game for two pairs of players.
noun A bridle is the set of leather straps you put around a horse's head and mouth so that you can control its movements.

adjective Something that is brief lasts only for a short time or takes only a short time. I was in Canberra for a brief visit last year. I wrote a brief note explaining my reasons. I'll be brief, as I know you're very busy.
noun A brief is a summary prepared for a barrister by a solicitor, giving all the information about a case.
noun A brief is also a set of instructions given to someone for a particular task. The new manager's brief was to reduce costs.
verb If you brief someone, you give them information and instructions to prepare them for a particular task. I'd better brief Sigrid before she goes to the meeting tomorrow.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See brevity. adverb briefly I saw her briefly the other day. I briefly summarised my concerns.noun briefing We all attended a briefing before the conference.

form.definition: noun A briefcase is a flat case made of leather or plastic that you carry papers and books in.

dictionary.entry:
brightbra:Itbrighterbrightest 1 adjective If something is bright, it has a strong noticeable colour or it shines strongly. I like to wear bright clothes. The door was painted bright yellow. The sudden bright light dazzled me. The
adjective Someone who is bright is intelligent, and can learn new things quickly. Amy should do very wellshe's a very bright little girl. He's a nice guy, but not too bright. That's a bright idea! It wasn't very bright of you to let the pan boil dry!
adjective You also say someone is bright when they are happy and cheerful. What makes you so bright and breezy today? I'm not feeling too brightI think I'm getting a cold. Sally's got a very bright personality.
... WORD FAMILY verb brighten This detergent will brighten your wash. He brightened at the news.adverb brightly The stars shone brightly. She answered him brightly.noun brightness You can adjust the brightness with this knob, and the contrast with this one.

form.definition: adjective A brilliant light or colour is one that is very bright. The sun was a brilliant orange.
adjective If someone is brilliant, they are very clever or talented. He's a brilliant young scholar. She gave a brilliant performance.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun brilliance The brilliance of the sun dazzled me. His brilliance was clear from his youth.adverb brilliantly She played brilliantly tonight.

form.definition: noun The brim of a cup, bowl or other container is its top edge. The tumbler was filled right to the brim.
noun The brim of a hat is the wide flat part that shades your eyes. You should wear a hat with a broad brim when you're out in the sun.
noun Brine is water with a lot of salt in it which you use to preserve some types of food.

dictionary.entry:
bringbrINbringsbroughtbringing 1 verb If you bring something or someone when you come to a place, you carry it with you or get them to come with you. Julio brought some beer to the barbecue. Can I bring my friend to your party? Animal and plant products could bring pests into
verb If something brings someone or something to a place or a condition, it causes them to be in it. We need to bring more tourists to Australia. The recession has brought many small businesses to the point of bankruptcy. What first brought you to the study of Japanese history?
bring about If you bring something about, you cause it to happen. Computers have brought about many changes in our lives. How can we bring about an increase in sales? The shock brought about his death.
bring down If something brings someone down, it causes them to fail. The scandal has already brought down three ministers. It was humid weather that brought down our athletes.
bring forward (a) If you bring forward a future event, you arrange for it to happen at an earlier time than was originally planned. Because of the crisis, the meeting has been brought forward from the 15th to the 7th.
(b) If you bring forward information or evidence, you produce it so that it can be considered or examined. He brought forward various documents in support of his claim. Why wasn't this issue brought forward earlier?
bring in (a) If the government or an authority brings in a new law or rule, they introduce it. We want the government to bring in further restrictions on the sale of tobacco. They've brought in new regulations for this season's races.
(b) If someone or something brings in money, they earn it. Amal brings in about $850 a week. Tourism brings in millions of dollars a year for Australia.
bring off If you bring something off, you are successful in achieving it. With careful planning and negotiation, Minh brought off the deal. Congratulations! I never thought you'd bring it off.
bring on If something brings something on, it causes it to come into existence. I wondered what had brought on her sudden friendliness. Eating too much fruit can bring on indigestion.
bring out (a) When an author brings out a new book, or a company brings out a new product, they make those things available to be sold. She's already brought out several volumes of poetry. It's essential to keep bringing out new models.
(b) If something brings out a certain type of feeling or behaviour in you, it makes you feel or behave in that way. When she starts to complain it brings out the worst in me and I get really angry.
bring round or around If you bring round someone who is unconscious, you cause them to regain consciousness. Another way of saying this is bring someone to. The ambulance officers brought Damien round after he'd been unconscious for nearly twenty minutes.
bring up (a) If you bring up children, you look after them until they have grown up. Val helped to bring up Steve's three sons. I was brought up to believe in the importance of politeness.
(b) If you bring up a particular topic in a conversation or discussion, you begin to talk about it. I wish you wouldn't keep bringing up the incident in public. There's one other point I'd like to bring up.
(c) If you bring up your food, you vomit. He got very drunk and brought up his dinner in the street.

form.definition: noun The brink of a cliff is its edge. Don't go too close to the brink!

If you are on the brink of something, you are just at the stage where something serious or important is likely to happen. The two countries were on the brink of war. I was on the brink of refusing the offer when something made me change my mind.

adjective If someone is brisk, they do things quickly without wasting time. Often they seem to be impatient and slightly rude. He can be so brisk that he frightens people. She reorganised our files with brisk efficiency.
adjective If something is brisk, it is refreshing and invigorating because it involves rapid motion. Every evening we go for a brisk walk round the park. The brisk breeze made me feel less sleepy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb briskly She briskly set about tidying up. He marched briskly out of the room.

form.definition: noun A bristle is a short stiff hair. This brush is made from pigs' bristles. After two days without shaving, his chin was covered with bristles.
verb If the hair on an animal's body bristles, it stands up from the skin because they are angry, frightened or cold. The hair on the dog's back bristled and it began to growl.
verb If something makes you bristle, you show that you are annoyed or irritated about it by the way you behave when someone mentions it. Pat bristled at the mention of Martin's name.

bristle with In informal language, if you say that a place bristles with people or things, you mean that it is full of them. There are a lot of them there. The streets were bristling with police after the bank robbery.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective bristly After a week he'd grown a bristly beard.

form.definition: adjective If something is brittle, it is hard but easily broken.
noun When you broach a subject, you start to talk about it. Many managers find it hard to broach the question of poor performance. We haven't yet broached the issue of finance.

dictionary.entry:
broadbr@:dbroaderbroadest 1a adjective If something is broad, it is wide. The distance across it, from one side to the other, is great. There was a broad band of cloud in the sky. He's wearing a white shirt with broad red stripes.
adjective Something is also broad if it stretches out for a long way in all directions. Australia has many broad plains suitable for growing wheat and grazing sheep.
adjective If something is broad, it is extensive and covers many different types of things. Ellie has a broad range of leisure interests. A broad range of people enjoy our concerts. The social club has a very broad membership, I'm glad to say.
adjective A broad outline or description describes something in general terms, not in detail. The first lecture gave us a broad introduction to the subject. 4 adjective A broad regional or national accent is very strong and noticeable. Rosanna still has a broad Italian accent.
... WORD FAMILY noun See breadth. verb broaden I'm looking for a new job to broaden my experience.adverb broadly That's the way it works, broadly. I broadly agree with you.

form.definition: verb A program or information is broadcast when it is sent out over radio or television. Thanks to modern technology, news of the disaster was broadcast within minutes. 2 verb If you broadcast information, especially something that is supposed to be a secret, you tell it to people so that it becomes widely known. I want to keep this quiet, so don't go broadcasting it around the office.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun broadcast Did you listen to the news broadcast?noun broadcaster He was a well-known radio broadcaster in the 1960s.

form.definition: adjective If you are broad-minded, you are tolerant of other people's behaviour and opinions. You are not easily shocked or disapproving. I wish my parents were as broad-minded as yours!
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is narrow-minded.

form.definition: noun Broccoli is a green vegetable. People cook and eat the stalks and flower heads.

noun A brochure is a small, thin book with a paper cover that gives you information about a product or service. It is often printed on glossy paper and has lots of pictures. The travel agent gave us lots of holiday brochures.
verb Broke is the past tense of break.
adjective In informal language, if you say you are broke, you mean you have no money. Can I borrow $20 from you? I'm completely broke until we get paid again.
verb Broken is the past participle of break.
adjective If something is broken, it has separated into pieces, usually because it has been dropped or hit. We'll have to fix the broken glass in that window.
adjective If an apparatus or piece of equipment is broken, it doesn't work any more because it has been damaged in some way. The yard is full of broken fridges and dishwashers.

adjective If you speak broken English or another language, you make a lot of mistakes because you don't know the language very well. I tried to give the tourists directions in my broken Japanese, but I wasn't very successful. 4a adjective A broken marriage is one that has ended in separation or divorce.
adjective A broken home is a family where the parents are separated or divorced.[xp\start\[ap--broker

noun A broker is someone whose job is to arrange for things to be sold by matching people who want to sell with people who want to buy. I phoned my broker to sell off some of my mining shares. ...an insurance broker. ...a wool broker.
noun A brolga is a large silver-grey bird with long legs and a red band on its head. It lives in northern and eastern Australia and is famous for its mating dances.
noun Brolly is an informal word for an umbrella.
noun Bronchitis is an illness which makes you cough because the lining of the air passages to your lungs is inflamed.
noun Bronze is a dark reddish-brown metal made from copper and tin.
adjective Bronze is also the reddish-brown colour of bronze.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective bronze ...a bronze ornament. ...a bronze silk blouse.

form.definition: noun A brooch is a small piece of jewellery that women pin to the chest of their clothes.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis word with broach.

form.definition: noun A brood is a family of young animals, especially birds. The mother hen was protective of her little brood of chicks.
noun Brood is also a humorous way of referring to a family of children, especially if there are a lot of them. Jeanette came round on Sunday with all her brood.

If you brood about something, you are worried about it and think about it all the time. This often makes you unhappy. Try not to brood on what happenedyou can't do anything about it now. I was brooding about how to get a better job. Stop brooding at home and get out and meet people.
noun A broom is a brush with a long handle. You use it to sweep a path or yard, or a tiled or wooden floor. Use a broom rather than a hose to clean the patio, and save water.
abbreviation for brothers, especially in the names of companies. I've been shopping at Grace Bros. today.
noun Broth is a thin soup you make with meat, fish or vegetables.
noun A brothel is a house where prostitutes work.
noun Your brother is a boy or man who has the same parents as you. You can also call a half brother your brother. People from some cultures also count their male cousins as brothers.
noun You can also call a man your brother if he belongs to the same race or religion as you, or has the same ideals.
noun Brother is also a title that certain religious groups give to their male members.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See fraternal. adjective brotherly

form.definition: noun Your brother-in-law is the brother of your wife or husband.
noun Your brother-in-law is also the husband of your sister. 3 noun Your brother-in-law is also the husband of the sister of your husband or wife.
verb Brought is the past tense and the past participle of bring.
noun Your brow is your forehead. He mopped the sweat from his brow.
noun Your brows are your eyebrows. This dye is not suitable for doing your lashes and brows.
noun The brow of a hill is its top or edge. Suddenly Janos appeared over the brow of the hill.

verb If you browbeat someone, you make them do something that they don't really want to do. You do this by nagging them or making them feel uncomfortable so that they agree to what you want. The kids always browbeat me into buying them toys. I felt browbeaten by the high-pressure sales technique.
noun Brown is the colour of earth or wood.
verb If you brown something, you make it become browner in colour. The strong sun had browned her skin. Brown the meat on both sides and then bake it for an hour.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective brown

form.definition: verb If you browse through a book or in a shop, you look through it casually to see what it contains. I browsed through a magazine while I was waiting.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun browse Can I have a browse through this book?noun browser The book shop is a browser's paradise.

form.definition: noun A bruise on your skin or on fruit is a dark mark caused by a blow or a fall. He came home covered in bruises. Don't buy those applesthey've got too many bruises.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb bruise I've bruised my arm. She bruises easily. Don't bruise the apples.

form.definition: noun A brumby is a wild horse living in the bush.
noun Brunch is a meal you have instead of breakfast and lunch. Often you do this at the weekends, when you get up later than during the week.
noun A brunette is a girl or woman with brown hair.

noun If you bear the brunt of something, you suffer the most damaging effects of it. The centre of the city bore the brunt of the earthquake. Poor Ed bore the brunt of the boss's anger. Small businesses have borne the brunt of the recession.

noun A brush is a set of hairs or bristles set in a handle. You use it for cleaning, smoothing or untangling something, or for painting. Where's the scrubbing brush? ...a nail brush. ...a hair brush. ...a clothes brush.
verb If you brush something, you clean it or tidy it with a brush. Don't forget to brush your teeth before you go to bed. You look a mess. Why don't you brush your hair?
noun If you give something a brush, you brush it. My suit needs a good brush to get all those cat hairs off.

noun If you have a brush with someone, you have a minor argument with them. Anjali's had a brush with his parents again. I remembered our earlier brush over the seating arrangements. Many of these teenagers have already had a brush with the law.

verb If someone or something brushes you, or brushes against you, they touch you lightly or gently. He brushed me on the elbow and whispered in my ear. The tall grasses brushed against her legs as she ran. The cats love to brush up against us. Her lips brushed his.
noun Brush is a dense growth of bushes and shrubs. The ball landed in the brush, and we never found it again.

brush aside If you brush someone or something aside, you ignore or reject them. Ping brushed aside all criticism. Brushing aside the crowd of reporters, he left the room. Workers' welfare has been brushed aside in the rush for profit.
brush off If you brush someone off, you refuse to listen or talk to them. Since our argument, every time I try to talk to her she just brushes me off.
brush up If you brush up a skill, you practise it again. If you brush up on a subject, you renew your knowledge of it. I'd better brush up my French if we're going to Noumea for a holiday.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun brush-off She gives me the brush-off whenever I try to talk to her.

form.definition: noun A brussels sprout is a dark green vegetable that looks like a tiny cabbage.
adjective If someone is brutal, they are cruel and savage, and have no sensitive human feelings. Pol Pot was a brutal dictator. Thousands have died in this brutal conflict.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun brutality Such brutality has become common.adverb brutally He was brutally murdered. She was brutally frank with me.

form.definition: noun A brute is a cruel person. These brutes get enjoyment from torturing cats.
noun You can also call a large animal a brute. As we approached, the brute snarled and rattled its chain. The horse broke its leg, so the poor brute had to be destroyed.

adjective If you say someone uses brute strength or brute force, you mean they use physical strength rather than intelligence to solve a problem. I fiddled with the lock for ages, but in the end Jack got the door open by brute force.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See brutal.

form.definition: noun A bubble is a small ball of air or gas in a liquid that rises to the surface. We could see where the divers were by the trail of bubbles. I don't like champagnethe bubbles go up my nose!

noun A bubble is also a small ball of air or gas with a thin outer layer of liquid that can float through the air or on water. The children had fun blowing bubbles with the soapy liquid. Look at all those bubbles! You've used far too much detergent.
noun A bubble is also a small ball of air or gas that is trapped in something. The sun had made the paint come up in bubbles. I looked for one without any bubbles in the glass.
verb When a liquid bubbles, bubbles rise to its surface. The water bubbled in the spa. Turn the gas down till the soup's just bubbling gently.
verb When a liquid bubbles, it moves along fast and makes a noise like boiling water. The stream bubbled over the pebbles.
verb If someone bubbles, they are very happy and lively. The kids bubbled with excitement at the prospect of going to the beach.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See bubbler. adjective bubbly This lemonade is too bubbly. She's got a lovely bubbly personality.

form.definition: noun A bubbler is a small fountain where you can get a drink of water.

noun A buck is what we call the male of a deer or rabbit. We call the female a doe. 2a verb When a horse bucks, it jumps with its back arched and all four feet off the ground. The stockman was thrown to the ground when the colt bucked.
verb If someone is bucked by a horse, they are thrown to the ground by its bucking.
noun Buck is an informal word for dollar. It costs about thirty bucks.
noun A bucket is a round open container that has a handle and is used to carry liquids. Buckets are made of metal or plastic, are wider at the top than the bottom, and have straight sides.

noun You can also use the word bucket to describe the amount of liquid contained in a bucket. To clean windows, just add a little vinegar to a bucket of warm water and wipe over the glass. The elephant drank six buckets of water.
verb If the rain buckets down, it's raining very heavily. It bucketed down all night.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bucketful [qr

dictionary.entry:
buckle`bV kl
noun A buckle is a clasp used to fasten a belt or strap. She was wearing a leather belt with a fancy silver buckle. There's something wrong with the buckle on this seat belt.
noun When something buckles, it becomes bent or distorted because of heat or pressure. The steel support buckled under the strain. I rode into the kerb and buckled the front wheel on my bike. Suddenly her knees buckled and she collapsed.
buckle down If you buckle down to something, you start working at it seriously. It's only two months to your examsdon't you think it's time you buckled down to studying properly?
... WORD FAMILY verb buckle Buckle your seat belt before you drive.noun buckle There's a buckle in the wheel.
bucktoothbV k`tu:Tbuckteeth noun If someone has buckteeth, the two front teeth in their upper jaw stick out prominently, so that they look a bit like a rabbit. ... WORD FAMILY adjective bucktoothed

form.definition: noun A bud is a flower or leaf before it has fully developed. It is rolled up tightly inside a protective cover. The buds will soon open in a warm room.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb bud (buds, budded, budding) This plant buds in spring.

form.definition: noun Buddhism is the religion founded by Buddha who lived in India around the 6th century BC.
noun A buddy is a close friend or companion. Reg is my diving buddy.
verb If someone or something doesn't budge, it stays where it is. It doesn't move or go away. Three days later, the yellow car still hadn't budged. Don't budge! I'll be right back.
verb If something won't budge, or you can't budge it, you can't make it move. The rock wouldn't budge. We couldn't budge the tree stump.

verb If someone won't budge on a matter, you can't convince them to change their mind or to compromise. Once my father has made up his mind about something he won't budge. After the divorce Mary refused to budge on the question of access to the children.
noun A budgerigar is a small green and yellow parrot that lives in the inland parts of Australia. Budgerigars are also kept in cages as pets, and varieties have been bred in many other colours.

noun A budget is a plan you make which shows how much money you expect to have each week or each month and how you will spend it. It's important to stick strictly to your budget. For those on a tight budget, they serve great food at low prices.

noun A budget is also the amount of money that is allocated to a particular task or project. The budget for the whole job is $200 000. The film went way over budget. She brought the report in under budget.
noun A budget is also a financial plan announced by the government. Often it contains changes to taxes and new regulations about them.

adjective Something that is described as budget is fairly cheap, and is generally more basic than other things of the same kind. We offer budget holidays for young travellers. The budget version comes without options, and costs only $399.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb budget I'm hopeless at budgeting. I budget $20 a week for entertainment.

form.definition: noun Budgie is a short form of budgerigar.
noun Buff is a pale brown or slightly yellow colour.
noun A buff is someone who is an expert on a particular subject, usually as a hobby. Bill Collins is Australia's best known film buff. John's a real chess buffhe's got shelves of books about it.
verb If you buff something, you polish it by rubbing. Will you help me buff the car after I put the wax on?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective buff ...a plain buff envelope.

form.definition: noun A buffer is something which absorbs a shock or protects something else from being harmed. The sea wall at the entrance to the harbour acts as a buffer against big waves during a storm. The brakes failed and the train ran into the buffers.

dictionary.entry:
buffet`bV fEI <for noun senses;> /\times,0\b... ft/ <for verb> 1a noun A buffet is a table or counter with many different types of food, from which you may serve yourself. The price includes unlimited visits to the salad buffet. That hotel does an excellent buffet for lunch. Will you be having the buffet, or would you
noun A buffet is also an informal meal at a party or other public occasion. You serve yourself food and eat standing up while moving around and talking to other people. There was a buffet after the wedding ceremony.
noun A buffet is also a low cupboard where you keep glasses, cups and plates.
verb When the wind or the sea buffets something, it hits, shakes or knocks it about in a violent way. The huge waves buffeted the small boat. The wind and rain buffeted our tent.

form.definition: noun A buffoon is someone who does foolish and ridiculous things. Stop playing the buffoon! Her father was a good-natured buffoon.
noun A bug is any small insect. The crop was ruined by a plague of bugs.
noun In informal language, a bug is a minor illness such as influenza, caused by a germ. Lots of people are off work todaythere must be a bug going round. I had some sort of stomach bug last week.

noun If you say that someone has the bug for something, you mean that they are very keen on doing it. After his holiday in Japan, Ken really caught the travel bug. She suddenly got the exercise bug, and started running several kilometres a day.
noun A bug is also a tiny microphone hidden in a room or inside a telephone. It is used to secretly listen to people's conversations.

verb If someone or something bugs you, they distract and irritate you. I can't work with the kids coming in and out and bugging me. The problem bugged me all day, but suddenly I realised the answer. It bugs me that she earns more than I do.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb bug Be careful what you saythe room may be bugged.

form.definition: noun A bugbear is something that worries you. I find installing computer programs a real bugbear. Young people often have bugbears about their appearance.
noun Bugger is an informal word for a disagreeable person. The bugger wouldn'tgive me my money back.
noun Bugger is also an informal word for any person or animal. I feel sorry for those poor buggers in the floods. They got the last tickets, lucky buggers. The bugger never stood a chance.
noun In informal language, you also call something a bugger if it causes you trouble or difficulty. This car's a real bugger to start. I can't get the bugger to print.

verb In informal language, if you say someone buggers something, you mean they break or ruin it. I'll never lend him anything againhe buggered my camera. This computer's totally buggered. The heavy rain buggered our picnic.
exclamation Bugger is also an informal word you use to show that you are annoyed. Bugger! It's raining and I've just hung out the washing. Bugger it! We've missed the ferry.
noun A bugger is also a man who practises anal sex, or an offensive term for a male homosexual.
verb If a man buggers someone, he has anal sex with them. If a man buggers an animal, he has sex with it.
bugger about In informal language, if you say someone buggers about, you mean they behave in a foolish way and waste time. Stop buggering about and get on with your work.
bugger off In informal language, if someone tells you to bugger off, they're telling you to go away. Bugger off! You're not wanted around here! I wish the kids would bugger off and leave us in peace.

bugger up In informal language, if you say someone buggers something up, you mean they ruin it or do it very badly. We all arrived at the same timethey'd clearly buggered up the arrangements. Inviting two more will bugger up my neat seating plan.
noun A bugle is a brass instrument used in the army to sound signals.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bugler

dictionary.entry:
buildbIldbuildsbuiltbuilding 1 verb If you build something, you make it by putting parts together. He built his own house. They're going to build a new hotel here. The wardrobe comes in piecesyou have to build it yourself. There are plans to build a new freeway. 2 verb If you build something, you form or develop it over a period of time. We've built a close relationship over the years. You need to build yourconfidence before tackling anything major. He's
noun Your build is the natural shape and size of your body. You need a light build to be a jockey. She has a heavy build. Because of his small build, he was chosen to try and squeeze through the gap. 4 build in or into (a) If you build a cupboard or a wardrobe into a room, you make it part of the woodwork rather than a piece of furniture that you can move.
(b) If you build something into something, you include it as a part of the whole. A safety clause is built into the contract. We must build in protection for existing workers.
build on (a) If you build on something, you develop it further. We must build on this success by launching more new products. Now you've achieved basic fitness, you must gradually build on it.
(b) If you build something on something, you develop it by means of the second thing. The region's economic boom is built on tourism. His success was built on hard work. She built her career on a number of high-profile prosecutions.
build up (a) If you build something up, you develop or increase it over a period of time. You need to build up your strength before the operation. He built up a successful import business.
(b) If something builds up, it increases in amount or intensity, often because no-one deals with it. Her anger had been building up for some time, and eventually she exploded. We must tackle the backlog that's built up.
... WORD FAMILY noun See building. noun builder I'm looking for a good builder to do my extension.adjective built-in Each bedroom had built-in wardrobes.

form.definition: noun A building is a structure with walls and a roof. How many units are there in your building? They're going to demolish those old factory buildings. It's one of the tallest buildings in the world.

noun A building society is an organisation that on the one hand accepts money from people and pays them interest, and on the other hand lends money to people to buy or build homes and charges them interest.
noun A built-up area is a place with a lot of houses, shops and people, and which has street lights. You mustn't have your headlights on high beam in a built-up area.
noun A bulb is a part of certain plants, such as onions, from which new plants grow.
noun A bulb is also the part of an electric light that has a thin wire inside glass which lights up when you switch it on. Another word for this is globe. The light bulb in the hall has blown.
noun A bulge is a swelling or lump in a flat surface. The wallet made a bulge in his jacket.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb bulge His wallet was bulging with money.

form.definition: noun Bulk is the size of something, measured by its length, width and depth. The freight shipment has a bulk of 200 square metres. Do you charge by weight or by bulk?
noun The bulk of something is most of it. I try to get the bulk of my work done in the morning. The main bulk of replies should arrive next week.
in bulk If you buy or transport something in bulk, you handle large quantities at a time. Grain is shipped overseas in bulk. Goods are often cheaper if you buy them in bulk.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective bulky (bulkier, bulkiest) It's not very heavy, but it's bulky. He wore a bulky overcoat.

form.definition: noun In informal language, bull is also nonsense or foolish talk. Sepp told me he fought and killed a three-metre crocodile, but that's just bull. Don't give me that bull!

noun A bullbar is a heavy metal bar attached to the front of a car or truck. It is there to protect the vehicle from being damaged if it hits cattle or kangaroos on country roads. See the picture at car.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is roo bar.

form.definition: noun A bulldozer is a large powerful tractor with a vertical metal plate at the front. It is used to demolish light structures and to move rocks and other large objects by pushing them. He threatened to send in the bulldozers when the protesters refused to move their camp. ... WORD FAMILY verb bulldoze The land was bulldozed clear of undergrowth. They bulldozed the huts.
noun A bullet is a small piece of metal with a pointed or rounded end which is fired out of a gun or rifle.
noun A bulletin is a short news report. Often it is an update on a developing story. Did you hear the latest bulletin about the plane crash?
noun A bulletin is also a brief report on news produced regularly by an organisation or club. Our diving club sends out a bulletin every month.
noun Bullion is gold or silver cast in the form of bars. Prices for gold bullion have risen sharply lately.
noun A bullock is a bull that has been castrated. Bullocks were often used to pull carts transporting heavy goods.
noun The bullseye is the small circle in the centre of the target in shooting or darts, or for firing arrows into. Sudha won the competition when she hit the bullseye.
noun A bullseye is also a shot or throw of a dart that hits the centre of the target and scores maximum points. You'll have to score a bullseye to win now.

In informal language, bullshit means nonsense. They're talking a lot of bullshit. Bullshit! You could do it if you wanted to. They spent a lot of money on bullshit like new furniture for the managers.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb bullshit Don't you bullshit me!

form.definition: noun A bully is someone who hurts or frightens people who are smaller and weaker than they are. Sean's a bullyhe keeps hitting the younger ones.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb bully (bullies, bullied, bullying) He bullies his younger brother. You can't bully me into doing it.

form.definition: noun Bum is an informal word for your bottom or buttocks.
noun If you call someone a bum, you mean they are lazy and careless. Come on you lazy bum, it's time to get out of bed! He thinks most of the unemployed are just bums.
verb In informal language, if you say someone bums something off someone, you mean they borrow it without intending to return it. Another word for this is bludge. Can I bum a cigarette off you?

bum around In informal language, if you say you bum around, you mean you spend your time not doing very much and without any clear purpose. 'What did you do in the holidays?' 'We just bummed around on the beach.'
verb If you bumble, you move or behave in a clumsy and awkward way, making a lot of mistakes. She bumbled into the room with a tray of drinks. The guy's a bumbling idiot!

verb If you bump something, you accidentally knock or hit it. I bumped my head on the low ceiling. My car bumped the garage door. 2 verb If your car bumps while you're driving, it bounces about because the surface of the road is uneven. The car bumped along the rough bush track. 3 noun A bump is a raised uneven part on a surface. I got a big bump on my head after I knocked it on the car door.

bump into If you bump into someone, you meet them unexpectedly or by chance. Guess who I bumped into today? We bump into each other from time to time at college. 5 bump off In informal language, to bump someone off means to murder them. He was suspected of having had several rivals bumped off.
bump up In informal language, if you say you bump something up, you mean you increase it. The high petrol prices have bumped up taxi fares. The accident will bump up the death toll for the year.
noun A bumper is a bar across the front or back of a car to protect it if it bumps into something. Another word for this is bumper bar.

adjective Bumper is used to describe something which is larger than normal. Next month's issue will be a bumper edition to mark our tenth anniversary. It looks as if we'll have a bumper crop this year.
noun A bun is a small round cake or bread roll.
noun A bun is also a mass of hair twisted and arranged at the back of your head in a tight round shape.
noun A bunch is a group of things gathered or joined together. I picked a bunch of flowers from the garden. She carried a large bunch of keys.
noun A bunch is also a group of people. A bunch of boys were playing in the backyard. They're a noisy bunch!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb bunch Don't bunch them all togetherspread them out a bit.

form.definition: noun A bundle is a group of things put together in a package. We tied the newspapers into bundles and left them out for recycling. The tramp picked up his bundle and set off.
noun In informal language, a bundle means a lot of money. Tamas made a bundle with that garage sale. I bet she earns a bundle.
verb If you bundle someone somewhere, you push or hurry them there. The police bundled him into the van. My mother bundled me out of the door before I could ask any awkward questions.
bundle off If you bundle someone off somewhere, you send them there in a hurry. At 8:30 every morning Sari bundles the kids off to school.
bundle up If you bundle up, you dress warmly. It's very cold and windy todaymake sure you bundle up before going out.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb bundle Bundle your clothes together.

form.definition: noun A bundy is a clock into which you put a card to record the time you start work and the time you finish.
When you bundy off, you put your card into the bundy to record the time you finish work. 3 When you bundy on, you put your card into the bundy to record the time you start work.
noun A bung is a plug for the hole in a wine barrel.

verb If you bung something somewhere, you put it there in a casual way. Just bung your bags in the boot. Bung it anywhere you can find room. I bunged my name on the list. We ought to bung up some posters. I always bung in lots of garlic.
noun A bungalow is a house with only one storey.

verb If you bungle something, you do it incompetently or fail in trying to do it. Pete bungled the navigating, and we ended up totally lost. The murder seems to have been a bungled kidnapping. ... WORD FAMILY noun bungle The whole thing was a disastrous bungle.
noun A bunion is a painful lump you can get on your foot, especially on your big toe. It is often caused by wearing shoes that are too tight.
noun A bunk is a bed that is fixed to a wall like a shelf. Bunks are commonly found in the cabins of ships and trains.
noun A bunk is also one of a pair of beds built one above the other. The twins fought over who was going to have the top bunk.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb bunk David bunked with us for two nights. Can I bunk on your floor tonight?

form.definition: noun A bunker is a very strong shelter under ground to protect people from guns or bombs.
noun A bunker is also a large container or enclosed area for storing coal or other types of fuel.
noun A bunker is also a curved area on a golf course that has been dug out and filled with sand. If your golf ball lands in this, it is very difficult to hit it out again.
noun Bunny is an informal word for rabbit, used especially when talking to children.
noun A bunny is also someone who is unlucky because they are left with the responsibility for an awkward or unpleasant situation.
noun A bunyip is an imaginary creature in Aboriginal legend who lives in swamps and billabongs.
noun A buoy is a large float anchored in the sea. Some buoys are there to warn sailors of dangerous spots and show them where they can safely go. Others are for tying small boats up to.
adjective If something is buoyant, it is able to float. Cork is an extremely buoyant material.
adjective If someone is buoyant, they are cheerful and lively. She encouraged us all with her buoyant good humour. I don't feel too buoyant at the momentmy work's getting me down.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun buoyancy

form.definition: verb If something burbles, it makes a bubbling sound, like water in a stream flowing over stones.

verb If someone burbles, they speak quickly and not very clearly so that it is hard for you to understand them. Shona burbled excitedly about her trip. You must practise giving your talk slowly and clearly, instead of burbling. I could hear the television burbling in the next room.
noun A burden is a heavy load to be carried. The camels set off across the desert with their burdens. The traveller put down his burden with a sigh of relief.
noun A burden is also a task or responsibility that may be difficult to bear. I like my new job, but the travelling's a real burden. I don't want to be a burden to my children in my old age.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb burden He was burdened with luggage. I don't want to burden you with my problems.noun burdensome I really love my mother, but her demands can be burdensome.

form.definition: noun A bureau is a desk with drawers and a cover that opens out to form the surface on which you write.

noun A bureau is also an organisation or a government office that collects and provides information. Anika works at the Australian Bureau of Statistics. I got some information about sightseeing from the tourist bureau. Why don't you contact the Bureau of Meteorology?

noun Bureaucracy is all the rules and procedures, some of which may be unnecessarily complex, that large organisations follow in their operations. I'm sorry about the bureaucracy, but could you fill in this form as well?
noun A bureaucracy is a system of administration operated according to strictly prescribed rules and procedures. I know it's annoying, but your request will have to go through the bureaucracy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See bureaucrat. adjective bureaucratic There's an incredibly bureaucratic procedure for obtaining stationery.

form.definition: noun A bureaucrat is someone who works in a bureaucracy and strictly follows all its procedures without using sensible judgment. It's hopeless trying to get any sense out of those faceless bureaucrats.

noun A burglar is a thief who breaks into your home and steals your possessions. We've put bars across our windows to stop burglars from getting in. ... WORD FAMILY noun burglary (burglaries) Burglary is a big problem in this suburb. That's our third burglary.verb burgle The house was burgled while we were out.
noun A burial is the occasion when a dead person or animal is put into a grave. I refused to go to the cemetery for my father's burial.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis with funeral, which is a service held, usually in a church or chapel, in honour of someone who has died.

form.definition: noun In informal language, if you say you give something a burl, you mean you'll try to do it. I've never been water-skiing before, but I'll give it a burl.
adjective If someone is burly, they have a strong and solid build.

verb If something is burning, it's on fire. I'd just got the wood in the barbecue burning nicely. The old warehouse burnt throughout the night. If the paper's damp, it won't burn properly. 2 verb If you burn something, you set it on fire and allow it to be consumed. It's illegal to burn your garbage in the backyard. He burnt all his papers the night before he died.

verb If you burn something you're cooking, you spoil it by using too much heat or cooking it for too long. The toast's been burnt black. Vera burnt the roast again. It's a real pain scraping the burnt bits out of the saucepan.

verb If you burn part of your body, you injure it by fire or something very hot, or by a chemical. I burnt my fingers on the stove. Don't lie in the sun too longyou'll burn your back. The acid burnt his skin.

verb If you say that something is burning, you mean that it is very hot or bright. The sand on the beach burnt beneath their feet. I came home to find all the lights still burning. The fabric was patterned with burning yellows and oranges.
verb If you burn with some emotion, you feel it very strongly. Her remark made him burn with anger. I still burnt with love for him.
noun A burn on your body is a wound produced by fire or something very hot, or by a chemical. That's a nasty burn! 30% of his body was covered with burns. ...a chemical burn.

burn down If you burn a building down, or if it burns down, it is completely destroyed by fire. Their house burned down in a bushfire. He tried to burn down his own factory for the insurance. 9 burn off If you burn off land, you clear it of trees and bushes by fire.

burn out (a) When a fire burns itself out, it stops burning because there is no material left for it to consume. We sat by our fire until it burnt itself out. Some bushfires in remote areas have been left to burn themselves out.

(b) If you burn yourself out, you get into a state where you can't work or be creative any more, because you've worked too hard in the past. Many of these young entrepreneurs burn themselves out by the time they're forty.
(c) When a building is burned out, the inside is destroyed by fire, leaving only its outside walls. The school was burned out in the big fire. The barn was reduced to a burned-out shell.
(d) If an engine or machine burns out, it stops working because it is damaged by the heat that the moving parts create. My electric drill needs to be fixed because it's burned out.
burn up If you say an engine burns up fuel, you mean that it uses too much fuel. A four-wheel drive is fun, but it really burns up fuel.
verb If you burnish metal, you polish it until it becomes bright and shiny.

verb If someone burps, they make a noise because air comes up from their stomach out through their throat and mouth. In Australia, it is considered slightly rude to burp in public. Fizzy drinks tend to make you burp.
verb If you burp a baby, you pat it on the back to make it burp up any air it's swallowed. Babies need to be burped after they've been fed, or they may get a pain in their stomach.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun burp He gave a loud burp, and several people looked round.

form.definition: noun A burr is a spiky seed case of certain plants. It took ages to pick all the burrs out of my socks.
noun A burr is also the rough sharp bits left on metal after it's been drilled or cut. You'd better file off that burr before you cut yourself.
noun A burrow is a hole in the ground which has been dug by an animal to use as a shelter. There are a lot of wombat burrows in the Snowy Mountains.

verb If you burrow through something, you use a digging movement in looking for something. She burrowed through the papers on her desk and produced the report. I burrowed in my pockets for some coins.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb burrow The rabbit burrowed into the ground.
