form.definition: noun A bursar is the person in a school or university who is in charge of the accounts and other financial matters.
noun A bursary is money given to school or university students to pay for their study expenses.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is scholarship.

dictionary.entry:
burstb@:stburstsburstbursting 1 verb If something bursts, or if you burst it, it suddenly splits and breaks open, often with an explosive noise. The balloon burst with a loud bang. Prick the sausages before you fry them, so they don't burst their skins. The bubbles floated away
verb If you say something is bursting with something, you mean it is very full of it. The room was bursting with people. Our next issue will be bursting with exciting ideas for holidays. I've eaten too muchI'm bursting. I'm bursting to go to the toilet.
verb If you burst into a room, you enter it suddenly with a lot of energy. The crowd burst into the stadium as the gates were opened. You can't just come bursting in here like thatyou must knock first.
noun A burst is a sudden short period of activity, noise or feeling. With a burst of speed he took the lead. Her entry was greeted with a burst of applause. Seeing him again brought a fresh burst of sorrow.
burst into (a) If you burst into tears or laughter, you suddenly start crying or laughing. The baby burst into tears at the loud noise. The whole room burst into shrieks of excitement.
(b) If something bursts into flames, it suddenly catches fire and begins to burn uncontrollably. The truck rolled over and burst into flames.
burst out (a) If you burst out laughing or crying, you suddenly start to laugh or cry. She burst out laughing at the suggestion.
(b) If you burst out saying something, you say it suddenly with a lot of feeling. 'You're a liar!', he burst out angrily.

bury`bEri:buriesburiedburying 1 verb If you bury something, you put it into a hole in the ground and cover it up with earth, usually in order to hide it. Our dog is always burying bones in the garden. They were searching
verb When a dead person is buried, they are put into a grave. I want to be buried next to my husband.
verb If something is buried, it is completely covered so that you can't find it. The letter was buried under a pile of papers and books. I'm sure the docket's buried here somewhere.
verb If you bury yourself in work or other activity, you occupy yourself completely with it. After the tragedy she buried herself in her work. The children can bury themselves in computer games for hours. I buried myself in my book, hoping they wouldn't disturb me.
... WORD FAMILY noun See burial.

form.definition: noun A bus is a long vehicle with rows of seats inside for carrying passengers. We'll catch the bus into town today.
bus stop A bus stop is a place on the side of a road where buses stop so that passengers can get on and off.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb bus (bussed or bused, bussing or busing) All the people going to the camp were bussed to the site yesterday.

form.definition: noun A bush is a low woody plant like a small tree, with branches coming out of its trunk close to the ground. The rose bush needs pruning. We lost the ball in the bushes.
noun Bush is also an area of land covered with trees and bushes. We went for a walk in the bush.

beat about the bush If you beat about the bush, you avoid coming to the point in a conversation. You do not talk directly about some important topic, but talk about other things or hint at what you mean, usually because you are embarrassed. Stop beating about the bush and get to the point! 4 go bush If someone goes bush, they leave the city and live a simple life in the countryside. I'm sick of city life, let's go bush for a while.
the bush The bush is the Australian countryside, as opposed to the city. People out in the bush are suffering badly in the drought.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective bushy (bushier, bushiest) The area is covered in bushy undergrowth. He has bushy eyebrows.

form.definition: noun A bush band is a group of musicians who play Australian folk music with instruments such as the violin, guitar and tea-chest bass. The bush band played 'Waltzing Matilda' and 'Botany Bay'.
adjective In informal language, if you say you're bushed, you mean you're very tired. We were bushed after walking all day.
adjective If you say you're bushed, you can also mean you're lost or confused. I was bushedI couldn't work out how to operate the video recorder.
noun A bushfire is a fire in a forest or bush country.
noun Bushie is a short form of bushman and bushwhacker.
noun A bushman is someone who is very skilled at living and surviving in the bush.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is bushie.

form.definition: noun A bushranger was someone who lived in the bush and robbed travellers. Mad Dog Morgan and Ned Kelly were famous Australian bushrangers of the 19th century.
verb When you go bushwalking you go walking through the bush for pleasure or for exercise. They go bushwalking in the national park every weekend.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bushwalk We go for a bushwalk most Sundays.noun bushwalker She's a keen bushwalker. The body was found by a party of bushwalkers.

form.definition: noun A bushwhacker is someone who lives in the bush.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is bushie.

form.definition: noun Business is making money by trading in goods or services. She's doing a course in business. He's away on business. We set up in business in 1980. They've gone out of business. What kind of business are you in? Business is very slack.

noun A business is an enterprise set up to make money, such as a shop or factory. Leonid has a small furniture business in town. The company grew into a substantial business. Many long-established businesses have failed during the recession.

noun Your business is the things that concern you and that you need to do. Mind your own business. That's none of your business. I've got a lot of business to clear up before going on holiday. I still have to sort out this refund business.
business hours If an office is open during business hours, it's open between 9 a.m. and 5 p.m. on weekdays.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective business ...business people. ...a business suit. ...a business loan.

form.definition: adjective If someone is businesslike, they handle things efficiently without wasting time. The meeting was short and businesslike.
noun A busker is someone who sings or plays music in city streets hoping people passing by will give them money for their performance. There are always a lot of buskers outside the railway station.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb busk He busks in town on Saturdays.

form.definition: noun A bust is a statue of a person's head, shoulders and upper chest. Minh has a bust of Mozart on the pianohe says it inspires him to play better.
noun A woman's breasts or bosom is also called her bust. She's always wanted to increase the size of her bust.

verb In informal language, if you say you bust something, you mean you break it accidentally so that it doesn't work any more. I busted my camera when I dropped it. 4 verb If you say the police bust someone, you mean that they arrest and charge them. He was busted for selling stolen goods.
bust up In informal language, when you say two people bust up, you mean they quarrel and end their relationship. Anjali's just busted up with her boyfriend. I didn't know Don and Emma had busted up.
go bust If a business or company goes bust, it has lost so much money that it has to close. High interest rates are making a lot of small businesses go bust.
noun A bustard is a large Australian bird that runs very fast and lives on plains where there is plenty of grass.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis word with bastard.

form.definition: verb If you bustle, you move quickly and busily. Samir bustled around tidying up and made everyone feel uncomfortable. She bustled importantly into the room.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun bustle I missed the bustle of the city.adjective bustling Out here you're a long way from the bustling city.

form.definition: adjective If you are busy, you are working hard or have a lot of work to do. I've been very busy this week. If you're busy now, I'll come back later. I was busy cooking when the phone rang.

adjective If something is busy, it is full of activity. The city's a busy placethere's always something happening. The town centre's always very busy on Saturday mornings. Did you find the roads busy?
adjective If a telephone line or a toilet is busy, it is already used by someone else. Another word for this is engaged.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb busily I was still busily tidying up when the guests arrived.

form.definition: noun A busybody is someone who has too much interest in other people's affairs and tries to interfere in them. Why can't the old busybody mind her own business!
conjunction But is a function word that can be used to join phrases and clauses, with meanings such as 'yet' and 'except'. You all went but I didn't. Everybody but me went to the party.
noun Butane is a gas that is used for heating, cooking and lighting.
adjective In informal language, if you say a woman is butch, you mean that she is masculine in her appearance and behaviour.
noun A butcher is someone who owns or works in a shop that prepares and sells meat. I need to go to the butcher on the way home.
noun You can also call a very cruel and violent murderer a butcher.
verb If you butcher an animal, you kill it and cut it up into pieces ready to cook and eat.
verb If someone butchers another person, they kill them in a very cruel and violent way.
verb If you butcher something, you make a terrible mess of it. I tried to sew the pocket back into the skirt but I butchered it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun butchery He recorded scenes of slaughter and butchery.

form.definition: noun A butcherbird is a grey and black Australian bird that hangs its dead prey on spikes and thorns.
noun The butt of something such as a rifle or a fishing rod is the thick blunt back end of it.
noun The butt of a cigarette or cigar is the end part that's left when you've finished smoking it. The streets were littered with cigarette butts.

noun If you are the butt of someone's teasing or criticism, you are the person they make fun of or criticise. Lana should stand up for herself moreshe's always the butt of their jokes. I'm sick of being the butt of your sarcasm.

verb If a goat butts you, it hits you with its head and horns. 5 butt in If someone butts in on a conversation or activity, they join in without being invited to do so. I can't stand the way he always butts in on our private conversations. I don't want to butt in where I'm not wanted.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun butt The goat gave me a strong butt on the leg.

form.definition: noun Butter is a fairly solid yellow substance made from cream. You can spread it on bread or use it in cooking.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb butter I was buttering bread for the kids' sandwiches. adjective buttery It's got a buttery taste.

form.definition: noun Butterfly stroke is a style of swimming where you lift both your arms out of the water at the same time, then bring them forward, and then back into the water and around again.
noun Your buttocks are the two round fleshy parts of your body on which you sit. The doctor gave me an injection in my left buttock.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body.[qr

dictionary.entry:
button`bV t@n
noun A button is a small, usually round, object used to fasten clothing. It is sewn to one part and passes through a slit in the other part to hold them together. You've lost a button off your shirt.
noun A button is also a knob on a machine that you press or turn to make it work. The button on the left controls the volume.
3 button up If you button up a garment, you do it up by fastening the buttons on one edge through the button holes on the other. You'd better button up tightit's cold and windy outside.
If someone tells you to button up, they're telling you to be quiet. Button up, we've heard quite enough about that.
... WORD FAMILY verb button I was buttoning my shirt when the door bell rang. Button down the collar.

form.definition: noun A buttress is a structure built against a wall to support it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb buttress

form.definition: verb If you buy something, you get it by paying money for it. I need to buy some new shoes. Money can't buy happiness.
verb If you buy someone's story or explanation, you accept it or believe it. The police won't buy that story. Did the boss buy your excuse?
buy out If you buy someone out, you take control of the business or property you both used to own by buying their share of it from them. Carlos bought his partner out of their business.
buy up If you buy up something, you buy all that is available or as much of it as you can. The property developer bought up all the best blocks in the district.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun buy These new shoes were a good buythey only cost $50.noun buyer John is a buyer for a large store in town.

form.definition: noun A buzz is a continuous sound like the one bees or blowflies make when they're flying. We could hear the buzz of conversation in the next room. The buzz from the chainsaw was driving me mad.

noun In informal language, if you say that a particular activity is a buzz or that you get a buzz out of doing it, you mean that you really enjoy it. You find it exciting. Our trip to Europe was a real buzz. John gets a buzz out of listening to music.
buzz off If someone tells you to buzz off, they're telling you to go away. Buzz off, mate, I'm busy.

give a buzz (a) In informal language, if you say that you give someone a buzz, you mean that you telephone them. Trish gave me a buzz on Friday to tell me the good news. (b) In informal language, if you say that something gives you a buzz, you mean that it makes you more alert. It stimulates you. Coffee always gives me a buzz. ... WORD FAMILY verb buzz The fly buzzed around my head. The room was buzzing with conversation. noun buzzer If you need the nurse, just press the buzzer.

dictionary.entry: bvd abbreviation for boulevard. It is usually used when you write an address. ... ANOTHER ABBREVIATIONfor boulevard is blvd.

form.definition: preposition By is a function word, with such meanings as 'near to', 'using' and 'not later than'. Wait for me by the post office. ...to come by train. ...to do it by Monday.
interjection Bye and bye-bye are informal ways of saying goodbye.

noun If you have a bye in a round of a competition, you have no opponent for that round and so you miss a turn. This often happens if there is an uneven number of teams or competitorsso each one has to have a bye. We've got a bye this weekend in hockeyat least we get ours over with early in the season.
noun A by-election is a special election held between regular elections to choose a new member of parliament when a sitting member has died or retired.
noun A by-law is a rule made by an organisation or local authority that is effective only within its own territory. You can read the railway by-laws on any station.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGof this is bye-law.

form.definition: adjective If you go to a BYO party, you take your own drinks with you. This usually applies only to alcoholic drinksoften soft drinks are available. ... NOTEThis is an abbreviation from the words bring your own. Another expression for this is BYOG, which is an abbreviation from the words bring your own grog.
noun A BYO is a restaurant where you can take your own wine or beer. For a small charge (called they will open it for you and provide glasses.

verb If you bypass someone or something, you avoid them. He bypassed the sensitive issue in his speech. She complained that she'd been bypassed in the decision-making process. The new expressway bypasses the town.
noun A bypass is a road built to avoid a town or busy area. Business in this town will be ruined when the bypass is built.

noun A bypass is also a surgical operation on your heart. In the operation artificial tubes are inserted to make the flow of blood go around a blocked or diseased part of your heart. He had a double bypass last year.
noun A by-product is something extra that is created in the process of doing something else.

noun A bystander is someone who is present when something happens, but doesn't take part in it. Police are anxious to interview bystanders who witnessed the incident. The bomb killed seven innocent bystanders.
noun A byte is a unit of information stored by a computer.

noun If you say that someone or something is a byword for some quality, you mean that they are well known for it. Our brand name has become a byword for reliability and excellence. Susan's a byword for punctuality around here.[fa[xp
